reviewText:
Video games often deal with larger than life situations, and yet it tends to be the simpler things that hit home the most. Borrowing elements from films such as Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button, and Pixar's Up, this is the story of a man on his deathbed attempting to fulfil his lifelong dream to visit the moon.

To go into anymore detail and risk spoilers would be a crime, but know that To The Moon stands as one of the most heartfelt stories of any game I have ever played, and when paired with the immaculate score composed by my much beloved Laura Shigihara, I can hardly imagine how someone could play through it without feeling something.

It's worth noting that what is here consists almost entirely of exposition. This is in by no means a slight against the game, just a fact that needs to be mentioned so you know what you are getting into. I realize that many have a disdain for games that barely warrant being described as such, but in this case I beg that they put aside those prejudices, as I feel if anything could change their minds To The Moon is it.

To say that Freebird Games creation was emotionally affecting to me would be an understatement. Despite coming close on many occasions, I can scarcely recall any game that managed to make me tear up the way To The Moon did. It's a remarkable achievement in not only videogame storytelling, but as a narrative in any medium, and you would be an absolute fool if you passed it up!

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
Wow.

To be brutally honest, I loaded this game up today thinking that I would just play around for a few minutes and then put it away, unlikely to ever play it again. In reality, from the point the story began to unfold I decided that I wouldn't ... or couldn't stop until it was completed.

It's amazing what Freebird Games managed to do with the RPG Maker tool. With some subtle animations, lighting, and movement, it didn't take long for me to forget the 'low budget' visuals and imagine as the game and story elements unfolded in whatever resolution my mind can create.

I will admit that this isn't what a person could call a gameplay heavy experience. However, the way that the elements are woven into the story are creative and even add to the story. I think as a medium we hurt ourselves by calling our games 'games' at all... however, I was able to complete the journey through my own interaction with enough perceived freedom that I didn't feel corralled into a corner. Mostly the story itself made me want to push to the next story element or conclusion... it was simply that good.

It's sad, really, that a small time developer like Freebird can craft something with such a small budget that is so moving, yet all the big AAA developers can hardly bring me to laugh let alone shed a tear. Speaking of laughter, the pacing of the story is impressive with some comic relief to mix up the joy and sadness. Although I will admit, a few times I thought one of the main characters was a little over-the-top silly... but that may just well be who he is.

When I was in college I took a movie class where the instructor said it was a travesty to ever watch a movie in pieces... and in this case, if you can free up a few hours, I think that this dish is best served in one sitting. Just keep a box of tissue next to your monitor.

reviewText:
There comes a time in life, sometimes, when you truly wonder about things. Wonder if, every day, there is a time and place for every action you do, every step you make, and sometimes you ask: Is it really worth it? I think like this a lot. Every action that goes on feels so insignificant. Yet, I got the chance to escape from a cruel world, in a world of hope, dreams, sorrow and..reality. With the help of a masterpiece, known as To The Moon, a critically acclaimed indie title released by FreebirdGames.

There are no words to describe this game. You might say it's beautiful, it's touching, amazing, inspiring, hopeful; and, yet, all of those would be true. But one cannot describe in sheer vocalized form what a journey this game takes an individual through. The game may be short, but it is an indescribable adventure through the memories and mind of John, exploring a beautiful, charming and, well, real world of memories he has. This game has so much charm, so much utter personallity, that it could rightfully be considered just one of the most beautiful masterpieces created in gaming. The music is awe-inspiring, the graphics charming and detailed, the characters, memorable and loveable..I don't think there could be a single thing to entail about this game in a negative light.

We, as gamers, often look at the things we play in electronics as, well, just games. They have plots, controls, gameplay, multiplayer, and aspects to look at. To The Moon is not like that. It's not a game. It's a story. Never, once, did I even consider this a game. It was something so beyond my grasp, something so beyond anyone's grasp of stories, that it genuinely brings a tear to the eye. Sure, there may be only 5-6 hours of gameplay, but every minute is a moment in this game. Every second brings something memorable and loveable for the player to enjoy, a sense of wonder and immersion that no game can truly offer like this one..
Honestly, I went into this game with low expectations. When I first heard about it, I scoffed. 'A game about going to the moon? What could that possibly entail?'. I later heard more about the game, watching the trailer and hearing about it from a very special, close friend of mine. As a birthday present, I received this game, and completed it the same day. It was an unforgettable trip. I could recommend anyone to this game and have no regrets what so ever.

Thank you, for taking me on this journey, my love.
It is one no one should be without.

It's on the Humble Indie Bundle X now but you should definitely pay the $10 to buy it on steam. The question I hope you will be left with at the end is, what does it really mean to be living the dream?

reviewText:
When your life comes to an end, what else is your life than the accumulation of your memories? To the Moon introduces the idea of having the possibility to rewrite your life in order to be content with it during you last concious moments on this planet, but  also presents you with the costs of doing so.
Besides having a filosofically interesting plot, this game features tonnes of little jokes and references that will keep the enjoyment up to scratch right from the start, all the way through the game, always knowing when it's appropriate to be funny.
This story is nicely accompanied by a lovely soundtrack that deserves to be picked up and having a listen to. Unless, of course, you have an intrinsic hate of piano music. The tracks are composed in such a way that they fit the individual scenes perfectly and add a genuine extra layer to the storytelling.
Playing this game for anything than its, frankly magnificent, storytelling capabilities would be a mistake though. Walking around feels like being in an outdated JRPG and further gameplay consists of non-imaginative puzzles that serve little purpose other than helping the player to not feel like they're watching a single cutscene.
Despite its flaws and being just a couple hours worth of an experience, I can do nothing else than recommend this wonderfully emotional piece of storytelling masterpiece, manly tears were shed. A must-play.

reviewText:
To the moon tells a wonderful story, of life, love and loss.  It's more a piece of art than a video game.  Anyone who enjoys a good story will enjoy this game.  If you're looking for cutting edge graphics, or state of the art gameplay this won't be for you.

In fact this game is pretty devoid of gameplay outside of moving from one scene to the next.  The game has some very simplistic puzzles which can typically be solved in under 10 moves.  Although game isn't about defeating enemies, gaining experience or collecting loot.

You play as a pair of... well they are called Doctors but I think they are more or less Scientist.  Their job is to go into someone memories, unlock the meories and use them to rebuild the memories in such a way as to fulfil their dying patients wish..

This story centers around a dying man named Johnny who wished to visit the moon.. hence the games title.. To the Moon.  Along the way of recovering Johnny's memory a wonderful story of love, and loss unfolds before your eyes..

This game is very good, it tells an amazing story, which if you enjoy stories, you'll love, if you are the pew pew pew, kill enemies, collect loot, gain levels type of guy, you should stay far away from this.

The game will last about 2 hours give or take a few minutes for solving the puzzles.  The ending will bring out the feelings in even the most hardened gamer.  Although as good as the story is, it can be pretty predicatable, although that isn't really a bad thing..

I'd recommend this game highly, great story, great music, and generally enjoyable enough..

reviewText:
The storyline was beautiful and funny. It made me feel as if true love no matter the obstacles or hardships you may face, it is worth tackling them together. Sometimes one may make sacrifices that others may not understand, not even the one they might of been intended for but its always for a dream.

Love is such a big word and can be expressed in many forms. The story really felt almost like a novella (soap opera)
One moment they are jerking your tears, the next you are smiling and that is what made it more interesting to continue playing. The twist in this game were on point and with some patience it really pays off to follow the game through the ending. Brace yourself though, ninja onions will pop out of nowhere towards the end!

Happiness is best shared amongst those you love the most.. family, friends, and that special someone.

“A dream you dream alone is only a dream. A dream you dream together is reality.”
― John Lennon

To The Moon, a game developed by FreeBird Studios, makes you play the role of two tech enthusiasts from Sigmund Corp who work to fullfill people's last wish. After a roadkill and a car crash, the two doctors arrive at their latest client's abode. An abandoned lighthouse, a large house with a sick man and his maid and grasslands with animals around is what the doctors find. But when they ask for Mr. John Wyles's dying wish, they get - He wants to go to the moon."

To The Moon's strong assets :-
A perfectly executed beautiful story which you'll play time and again.
Simplistic gameplay.
Enchanting music which keeps hold of you for a time long enough.
Sceneries embellished by 16 bit graphics.
Well scripted dialogues making you laugh and heartfelt at the same time.
Adorning the atmosphere are the strongly developed characters.
A spellbinding lasting appeal.

reviewText:
To the Moon gets a lot of praise for it's story, and I'm happy to say it lived up to my expectations. There is very little gameplay to be had, the 'game' is about the journey you go on, slowly going back through John's life piecing things together.

I was warned that I would be in tears playing this, and there was a little part early on that got me blubbering, perhaps because it hit a little too close to home in that circumstance. As I approached the end of the story, I was ready and waiting for the part that would hit my emotions, as I had been told the ending was quite a tear-jerker. Just as I thought the game was coming to a close and I had missed it, it hit me. I was a blubbering wreck as the story tied everything up and came to a close.

To the Moon will not thrill you with revolutionary gameplay and mechanics. However, it will take you on a journey that will captivate you and leave you feeling such strong emotions for the little pixelated people.

'Play' To the Moon, it's quite the journey.

reviewText:
An Impassioned And Engrossing Story // A Perfect 'Rainy Day' Title
+ Astonishing soundtrack that will stay with you long after completion
+ Successful injections of humor and self-awareness pervade throughout the tale
+ Memento puzzles are a breath of fresh air, and are placed in a way that does not offset the pacing or the narrative
+ Has a lot of emotional depth; at times, it is really quite overpowering
+ Narrative is novel and well-written
+ Characters are relatable, charming, and their interactions have a deep impact on the player

- No audio/visual/control options of any kind
- No alternate endings or unlockable content; in addition, the extremely linear playthrough leaves little in the way of replay value

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText: Concise and beautiful.\nIt's a short game, but I would definitely say it's worth the purchase. The soundtrack is superb, it evokes a lot of emotion. I personally find it important to have a good soundtrack let alone a great story. I loved the way they progressed through the story backwards and still successfully made the game play out smoothly. I wouldn't suggest buying this game if you're purchasing games for gameplay or graphics. To the Moon is basically a story but you have to push buttons to read it. When I first began the game, I had a mindset where I believed the story was going to be linear, predictable. But I was wrong! I found myself wanting to know more, because a lot is left out and told to you later. I didn't think the game was too short

reviewText:
While some games are easily memorable for their gameplay, others will stood out by their Story. To the Moon is a game where the story is clearly the winner and it’s the reason why everyone should spend their time playing it. I’ll start by saying that it may not be a game that will please most of the players but consider starting the game with an open heart and the experience will be a remarkable one. The two main characters are doctors who go by the name of Watts and Rosalene and their jobs can be many things, but common isn’t one of them. They can provide an alternative, a different path to the ones whose life is approaching the end. During the story, your role is to help your patient to fulfil his wish: going to the moon. While it may seem an odd thing to wish for, there may be a reason for it, but that, is up to you to find out.

You start by going from the most recent memories to the older ones, until you reach the point where you may find key-points in the Johnny’s past. But as you advance in the game you start to create a bond to his memories which can be odd, considering it’s just a job and Johnny is a stranger for you, but remember, if you let yourself immerse into the story you will end playing a much better game this way. There’s not much to be said about the Story itself without spoiling most of it to be honest. The game is very straight to the point, hence its short length but this can be a good thing because there won’t be any unnecessary time spent doing pointless quests or wandering off for long. You have a goal, this is your job and emotions should be left aside, but play this game as intended and emotions will surely make part of this experience. As they should.

The music/soundtrack is as much important as the story because during certain events you will be listening to a nice piano tune that will provide warm feelings or a sense of loss, sadness and curiosity. I don’t believe the game to be any sort of depressing, as humor also plays an important role in To the Moon. Small conversations with some jokes and jests will arise from time to time to create a lighter mood since, after all, this is your goal and you shouldn’t let your personal feelings obstruct your intents. While I’m sure many will leave satisfied with the story (weather you end up liking the very end or not) and the music as well, do not come expecting some heavy gameplay mechanics or a rather lengthy game. I believe its short size can be a strong point this time because it takes you right where you need to be so I would advise to not measure your time and money invested with the length of the game but rather in its storytelling. If you are able to past the simple visuals with almost no gameplay mechanics, and if you let yourself engage in the Story while listening to the wonderful soundtrack then To the Moon will be a perfect fit to play in the between of any other lengthier games you are currently playing. It’s a respectable violence-free game, short but sweet experience filled with some humor, remarkable music and probably some tears as well. Play the game as intended, do not haste, do not do anything else while playing it and I’m sure your money will be a good investment. Enjoy the story.

PS: As you may have noticed, English is not my first language so I apologize for the lack of a better grammar and steady writing.

Have you ever met someone who loves doing a job for dying people, making their wishes come true? Its story simply, quietly, gently, made me shed tears. After I finished the game, I re-played all soundtracks and still felt so much feel. Give it a try. I'm sure It'd be worth every bit of both your cent and your time.

reviewText:
No need to tell about the story - you already read about that in the description, so I just want to tell about what it is to be played. It is the most emotional and heart touching game for me.
Because of the graphic style it doesn't look like a classic p&c adventure game at first sight, but it really is! Nothing for those that need hard puzzles to enjoy a game though.
Some people might prefer to classify it as a kind of interactive story because of the easy puzzeles but that's not the point here.
It touches your heart deeply and I read a lot of times about adults commenting that were stirred to tears or cried during the play while the story enfolds more and more (also males!).
Several games managed to catch me at some scenes or with the story (sometimes sad and sometimes funny) but I never finished a game crying before this one.
Also Laura singing that song is really awesome.

This game will leave you with lots of thoughts about life and death, dreams and much more ...  so be prepared.

reviewText: On occasion in life you come across a moment, or in this case game that you simply feel fortunate enough to witness or again in this case play, and To the Moon is definately one of those games. To the Moon is set in a world where scientists can fullfil and create memories and thus giving John who is the centre charector a chance to complete his final wish to travel  To the Moon . You play as two of these scientists and it becomes clear early on that visiting people's memories to fullfil these wishes is just part of their job,  and that they hold no emotional ettachment with their clients. As the story unfolds you are forced to visit John's unpleasent memories which are tied together with completing this wish, as the two scientists witness these remininescences of the past they begin to connect with John, you slowly begin to see that in this special case they no longer consider it their duty nor their obligation to fullfill this task but too do it out of good will - they begin to care for him. As the story progresses it takes you on an emotional rollercoaster, like the two scientists the theme transferred i started to care for John. This game moved me like few others out there can and I would like to thank the main developers and in addition the main writer of the music  Laura Shigihara.\nIf i was to describe this game in one word it would simply be Beautiful. 10 / 10

reviewText:
To The Moon is a little perl in this big sea of Indie games.
The games has been developed by Freebird Games using RPG maker.
The basic idea is simple: tell a good story.
Lots of people would think something like “then it's like every game”; well they are completly wrong.
The plot is based on two scientists that, via an extraordinary machine, can see the memories of the person who is testing it and making his/her least dream come true throu an illusion.
One day they reciene this request from an old man who lives in a manor near a lighthouse.
His last dream is going to the moon; a simple request but that it will be revealed to be more complicated than the usual.
Viewing the memories of the man you will discover an importand truth that will change the story deeply.
The story of To The Moon is not an ordinary story, this game manages to touch the deepest part of your heart.
You will laugh and cry with the characters because it's nearly impossible rexist to the magic of this game.
The mechanics of the game are simple: find objects, solve little enigmas and go through the story.
Also i would like to mention the extraordinary work that has been made with the soundtrack of the game.
Every track is perfect for every scene is setted and it's just pure poetry; orchestral music at the highest quality.
In my opinion buying the Soundtrack DLC is really worth it because we are in front of an excellent work.
There are some glitches but they are all passable.
The conclusion is that To The Moon is a little masterpiece that deserves an important place in your library of games and that everyone can appreciate.


My vote: 9.5/10

reviewText: To the Moon is a story-heavy, well executed lovestory by FreeBirdGames. It's about two doctors that travel to fulfill a dying mans last wish. The story is told in a very different way. You controll these two doctors through a bunch of memories. The memories are about Johnny life and his love for River. It's about how he lived his life and what happend during it. Time- travelling, puzzle solving game with much dialogue. The music in this game, mostly piano music, is freaking amazing. It's right on time, very fitting. The conversation between the doctors is really fun. It's good, because the rest of the story is very sad and emotional. The doctors argue about anything really, from olives to driving skills. It made me smile several times. If I had to say something bad about the game? The controls. Sometimes you click and the characters dont really move as you want them to. It can be a bit awkward, but its not that much of a problem since it's mostly just dialogue and not that much moving around. The puzzles are simple, yet fun. To be honest I really like when they're simple because I think hard puzzles are just off-putting and frustrating in a story-heavy game like this. If you happend to like pixelgames or just want a game focused more on story then gameplay, then this is the game for you.

reviewText:
To enjoy this game, you must meet two criteria:
First, you must focus on the story.
Second, you must have a soul.
Then, you will find this short tale captivating, emotional, and stunning.
Like I said, the story is the focus. The gameplay revolves around exploring until you find enough secrets to unlock the next level. This can get repetitive, but is really the only downside.
A huge upside is the soundtrack. It's beautifully done piano that adds to the emotion and nostalgia that ties in the present with your exploration of the past.
This game is short and cheap, so you don't have much to lose. But if you play it, I think you will find you won't lose anything.

reviewText:
I'll be frank: When I first started playing this, I thought it was just some soulless 2D game, quickly slapped together, throwing text in where it pleased and passing itself off as art. Shallow. Boring. Pretentious. But I wasn't very far in. I knew it wasn't fair to judge a game without giving it a proper chance.

So I kept playing, in the beginning forcing myself, assuming it was just another overrated artsy game with no real meat to it. Well I was wrong; without noticing, I began to feel myself compelled to keep going, the feeling growing stronger the longer I played. Soon enough, I almost literally had to see the next part. I actually played it all in sitting, unable to pull myself away despite it having kept me up past 5 in the morning at that point.

It drove me on relentlessly, leaving me constantly wanting to know what was next, and why such-and-such a thing happened... why characters were who they were. I kept thinking I came to a conclusion, when once again it would twist my thoughts.

I came to the brink of tears repeatedly towards the latter part of the game. I winced when I saw something bad happen. I smiled for the characters when they were happy. It ripped my heart out to see them suffer. And then I realized – I’m feeling so strongly for a bunch of pixelated sprites, not even realistic looking things… this game is THAT powerful.

I told myself again and again, “Don’t cry. Don’t cry. It’s just a game.” But when the ending came, there was nothing I could do. The waterworks were coming whether I liked it or not.

That’s not to say the game is depressing. Far from it: It’s sad, it’s happy, it sprinkles in humor when it knows it needs to… and it ends in such a way that your tears most certainly won’t be of sadness. It pulls at your heart and mind simultaneously; it makes your emotions come out full force and provokes your thoughts with the many questions, both story and real life related, it poses to the player.

Quite simply, it was -the- most moving, beautiful game I’ve ever played, and I recommend it to absolutely everyone.

Buy it, play it, and don’t stop until the end.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying I ♥♥♥♥ING HATE RPG MAKER GAMES.
That being said.... this game is now in my top 10 favorite games of all time, in fact, it's probably even top 5.... I just cried so much in front of my stream viewers. This game will make you laugh, feel uncomfortable, and cry, all in a neatly compacted story line. This game is ALL story. There is no filler, everything serves a purpose, and that purpose is so....so....SO beautiful.

I was hesitant to play this game...and for that I can only apologize to myself....

I shouldn't have been.

10/10, I recommend it to everybody reading this.

reviewText:
It's one of those games you inevitably hear about, want to try, and then start playing it and realize that it's not that great technically, that characters need a lot of time to exit a car and get to the house, that you'll have to stop for a dialogue every now and then... Not something you can just play anytime, you have to leave it for the right moment.

Luckily, I had a new reason to get back to it, and last night decided to download it again and give it a second chance. I could write about the game, I could write about me playing it and feeling this or that, but I think it should be enough to say that, after a short time, I realized it's past 5 am and I had to be at work soon. Yes, the game is slow to grab you, but once it does... omg! After just a few 'jumps' you get this horrible feeling of something being really wrong, and the need to find out what it is surpases the simple wish to play the game and finish it. It is what holds you glued to the screen to the very end, what forces you to learn how to solve those short puzzles faster so the story can continue as soon as possible, what will keep you playing even during the otherwise stupid horse riding scene, which is totally wrong for a game like this in a technical sense and could have destroyed it completely by forcing people to quit... if not for the gripping storytelling that simply does not let you move away.

It's a game that I will think about a lot, and that, more than anything else, makes it a work of art.
It's a well written animated book, with characters full of life, well motivated and engaging. It's something that will stop the world for you, and make you sad knowing that not everyone will have the will to give it a chance. But they should. And you should, even if it does has some annoying features. What game does not have them?

reviewText:
Wow.... I literally just finished this game and I'm at a loss for words.  But I really feel that I can't let this one go without saying something about it....

I guess first things first.... the story is absolutely beautiful!  A perfect love story through and through.  Even with its simplistic pixel art style, it did everything right to tug at the heartstrings something fierce.  Accompanied by the wonderful music score, the story really just comes to life.  A total masterpiece!

To be honest, I'm now sort of feeling a bit ashamed because I don't even know how this masterpiece came to be in my library.  I was prepared to just let it idle for the cards, but then I gave it a chance on advice from others and actually started to play it.  And now I'm extremely glad I did!

This piece of art is definitely worth playing.  If you're contemplating buying it, I think you'd find it worth it even at full price.

11/10 for sure!

reviewText:
Short story-rich 2D retro adventure with great atmosphere, interesting plot, heartbreaking moments & boring longueurs

What I liked

Deep atmosphere for a 2D adventure
Interesting plot, interesting characters, lovely heartbreaking love story
Decent 2D pixel graphics from the age of Secret of Mana / Chrono Trigger
Short game, perfect for one session the weekend or in the evening after work
100% achievements after first playthrough (around 3,5 hours)

What I didn't like

Unnecessary long dialogues
Street language does not really fit the atmosphere
Humour is not mine
Controls with mouse and keyboard are clunky
Repetitive in the middle of the game
Zero replay-value

Recommended for what it is: a short lovely 2D game.

reviewText:
An all-round great game, I would say.

I heard that this game was emotional and tragic, but had a great story. So I kind of went into this expecting to be incredibly depressed by the end. Fortunately it’s not all that bad.
It has a very emotional story to it but all in all it’s a wonderfully imaginative game with a satisfying ending.

Character wise, there is a nice contrast between what I guess you would call two sets of main characters. You have the couple who are followed throughout the game, and the work colleagues, that are doing the following. I say ‘contrast’ because they are pretty much opposites of each other. The couple are in love and are going through their struggles together in a very emotional way, whilst the two work colleagues are that typical brother/sister relationship. Messing around, insulting each other and generally just being a very comedic pair.

The music in this game is absolutely amazing. It is integrated into the game wonderfully and it really does get those emotions going at the right times. Now, as a girl I cried a fair few times. My brother rolling his eyes as if to say ‘typical woman’ after asking if I had finished it, me swinging round with that ‘I wasn’t crying, I had something in my eye’ look. But even with that taken into account, I still think this is something that guys can enjoy as well. Maybe they won’t ‘cry’ like I did, but it still tugs on those heart strings.

Story wise, I have to admit it’s not anything like I imagined it would be. I knew there was going to be a couple, a struggle and a few heartbreaking moments, but I never thought the story would be set how it is. It’s really a very surreal kind of game that I guess can be compared partially to Inception. These work colleagues are hired to do a job inside the head of their client. Which opens up a lot of possibilities for the story. It isn’t as predictable as you might think and it brings a lot of neat game mechanics with it.

Finally, the graphics. I love this style of graphics and whenever I’m recommended a game with this kind of style it is always going to be something I will try. I don’t even know what you call it but I just refer to it as the Pokémon-game-ish-style. It makes the game even more unique then it already is, and strangely enough, at one point while I was playing it, I actually got the feeling that if the graphics were any different it wouldn’t be as easy to get so attached to the characters and generally get into the game. The simplistic graphics actually make it what it is, in my own opinion.

All in all, it’s a wonderful game and I think it is definitely worth a try for those who like a good story.

TL;DR : Great characters, beautiful music, good story and pleasing graphics. Emotional but well worth the time put into it. Buy it!

reviewText:
9.5/10
So... You're here to take me to the moon?

Overview
To The Moon doesn't offer much in the gameplay department. It doesn't present stunning visuals nor is it particularly exciting... But it doesn't pretend to offer any of those things. It's short, honest, beautiful and emotionally consuming. A solid piece of masterful storytelling.

Story
The story follows the whimsical Dr. Neil Watts and level-headed Dr. Eva Rosalene, high-ranking employees of the Sigmund Agency of Life corporation, a service that specializes in altering a terminal person's memory before time of death in order to make their dreams come true. Basically, they're selling deathbed happiness.

To The Moon isn't a comedy, though it's hilarious. It isn't a tragedy though it's heart-rending. What it is is brilliant. The dialogue is as powerful and relatable as the thematic is harrowing. I don't want to go into too much detail about the story; I want you to experience the twisty narrative of it by yourselves.

Gameplay
At first glance, the game plays like you'd expect an RPG to play, minus any form of combat or statistical management. The gameplay mechanics are bare-bones: You walk around, talk with people and interact with objects to progress in a linear fashion. The walk-and-interact gameplay is briefly diversified every now and then with a series of flip-tile puzzles. These are never too difficult and are not detrimental to the experience in the least. Other unexpected gameplay elements are also introduced for brief segments, all of which are an appreciated change of pace.

Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene enter the mind of John (their patient) and start off in a late memory. They need to understand the patient's history in order to progress farther back into his past and construct variables to influence the patient's future. The goal is simple: Work your way through John's memories and spark the changes that will alter his future forever.

Audio
The original soundtrack may be the strongest aspect of the game. It's strongly in-tune with the emotions that the game attempts to pull out of you and often feels like it leads the resulting impressions. I can't lie, I had to hold back tears to Laura Shigihara's Everything's Alright" when it ripped the limelight from the scene during which it's presented.

Technical
Though the game isn't a technical marvel in itself
date: the user interface is pretty bland and appears "cheap". The lack of options or settings is odd and the game does not support the Steam overlay. These are all very minor shortcomings and I could only bring myself to shave off a fraction of a point for these. The game otherwise runs well
recommended:
saves automatically to prevent progress loss and it all just works.

The TL;DR
An engaging fable of love
hoursPlayed: waning time and the human condition it encompasses. A tale of fabrication and untruth. This is a story you likely won't soon forget. It lingers with you. A tragic comedy.\n\nTo The Moon is a success. A brilliant
voteText: sense-shattering success."

reviewText:
To the Moon is a game that wants to be played; no.  It DEMANDS to be played.

I'll be the first to say that the 16-bit gameplay isn't earth-shattering.  I'll also say that the minigame that is a part of the forward gameplay isn't particularly masterminded...just being a sliding puzzle.  Yet here I am still writing a review on To the Moon because it has still left a footprint on me.  What does set this game apart however  is the impeccable writing and story.  There are moments you find yourself smiling at the humor, and there are moments you find yourself saddened with the emotional connections you are making with the characters.  I finally broke down to purchase this game during the Autumn Steam Sale because of all the rave things I had heard on reddit.com from users about this game.

The game will take only about 4 HRs of your time, and most certainly will leave you yearning for more storytelling like this.  This musical composition is near genius with original pieces, and the fact that they were able to make such a moving game on this kind of medium says more than anything my review ever could.  THIS is why we support Indie games.  I can still tangibly feel the heart and soul that were placed with love into this game.

reviewText: To The Moon is probably the most difficult game I’ve had to recommend so far: mainly because I have mixed opinions on various aspects of the game. For the most part, I enjoyed the it, and can agree with what a majority of steam users have to say about this splendid game. But while I found it enjoyable, it's not without its problems.\n\nThe main premise of To The Moon is that two doctors-Eva and Neil (which you'll be playing as)-work for a company that reconstructs" dying people's memories so that they can pretty much live their life again without any regrets. The patient in question that Eva and Neil must help is a man named Johnny
date: a dying old man who dreams of going to the moon. Without trying to spoil much
recommended: Eva and Neil will travel throughout Johnny's memories so that they can alter his life so that he eventually becomes an astronaut that reaches the moon (It’s a cool and simple premise that is easy to understand
hoursPlayed: and becomes even more interesting when you look at it through a symbolic point of view). They’ll also learn about his relationship with a girl named River and exactly why Johnny wants to go to the moon.\n\nThe gameplay consists of you wondering around Johnny's memories looking for important moments/objects in his life so that you can go back further into Johnny's past (ex:  a toy that he's treasured all his life
voteText: or a life changing event). There really is no action in the game (the screenshot[cdn.akamai.steamstatic.com] on the store page depicting a turn based battle is incredibly misleading
helpfulPercent: since it's only used on one part as a joke)
votesHelpful: although this is not a bad thing. Looking for the hidden mementos (and solving the puzzles at the end of each section) is actually kind of fun
votesTotal: and in narrative games like this
votesFunny: sometimes it’s best if there is less action. So if you’re the type of person that only plays games that involve action/fighting

although this is a minor problem).


So why exactly did I not find it fully enjoyable? I think the answer would be with the two main characters: Eva and Neil.

Throughout To The Moon

reviewText:
Absolutely incredible game. Every aspect of it comes together with perfection. A heartfelt story, beautiful, yet simple graphics, and one of the best game soundtracks I have ever heard.

This game tells a story in a beautiful way, and keeps you glued to the screen throughout. Mixing sentiment and humor well. The game is about 3-4 hours long , but worth every penny. I got this game as a gift and feel like it is just one of those games you need to share with someone you care about, and I will.

Buy the soundtrack too. It fits the game like a glove, but as a standalone playlist of music it can be enjoyed anywhere. Not to mention that they donate 50% of the soundtrack price you pay to charity.

Even if you are not a point and click adventure fan you may find that this game will make you one. It might be my favorite adventure game I have played to date. Highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
[SPOILER FREE]
I simply can not state how this game made me feel during it's last hours and especially in the end. This is one true masterpiece, a game to be forever remembered for it's unique storytelling, dialogue and characters. The game gets really emotional in a way I've never seen since Mass Effect 2 (Yes, it is THAT good), but it also features great sense of humor, really nice pixelart and an incredible - to say the least - soundtrack.

The only flaw I see in this game is the lack of an options menu, since the game apparently doesn't run at the native resolution of your desktop.
Overall, I believe that any story driven gamer should play this.
Strongly recommended.
9.3/10

reviewText:
Not an actual game, but that doesn't prevent you from crying to it.

To the Moon is one of the best games I have ever experienced.

It's about two doctors trying to fulfill an old, dying man's wish of going to the moon. And that's about everything I can really say, as saying anything more than that would spoil it.

The game is designed really, really well, has lovely graphics, and on top of the amazingly written story (which is so emotional that my eyes have teared up - twice) is the breathtaking music that just makes it all feel even better.

In terms of content and size, To the Moon is short and you can finish it in one sitting during a rainy afternoon, while offering little to no replayability value. So is it worth your money? Yes.

reviewText:
I just.. I sat down and did this game start to end and simply couldn't put it down. It's incredibly powerful and sad. There have been a very small handful of stories that I'd say have made a really deep impression on me, something I end up remembering for the rest of my life, those tales and characters that are so touching and poignant that they sort of become part of me, making me want to dedicate and live my life for them and succeed where they could not, and become a better person that way.

This is one of those stories. And I absolutely will not tell you the plot of the story. I could never do it justice. The game presents all these weird puzzling plot items and ideas at the start of the game, but then ties them together in Act 3. My gosh. It hit me so hard.

The game flirts with existential philosophy, and that is referenced a couple times by the characters but is more an undertone of the game rather than the main focus and story. There is also a fair amount of banter and humour between the two playable characters, that had me laughing out loud on occasion.

It has a very linear plotline and map and is written in the RPG Maker XP engine. Slightly clunky UI, the windowed mode is incredibly small and unable to be resized, so the game is meant to be played full screen. Nothing too egrerious however, I found a couple small annoyances like movement obstacles and not knowing where to go during the horse part, but they were easily ignored. The soundtrack is simple and haunting and even plays a minor role within the story.

reviewText: Put simply the best story driven game I have ever seen, this game has a better made story than some best selling books in my opinion. To the Moon is a beautifully written game that brings tears to my eyes one minute, creeps me out the next and after it's done all that it makes me laugh like an idiot, a big factor of this is the music. The mainly acoustic piano soundtrack is amazingly written to fit each situation, so well in fact it made me actually look up the sheet music, print it out and start learning the pieces. To the Moon is full of story and tons of humour that can make you laugh out loud, it deserves every single good recommendation it gets. If you love a good book pick this game up and play it, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: This game is beauty and art in their purest forms. I've read a lot of books, I've watched a lot of movies, and I've played a lot of games, but never have I come across something that has caused me so much emotional turmoil and heartwrenching bittersweet feelings than this simple visual novel. The visuals are beautiful, the music consistently compliments the mood so well while being some of the best songs I've ever heard, and the characters are so well developed I could reach out and touch them.\n\nWhether you love games or have never played one before, whether you cannot stop reading novels or have only picked up books required by your classes,  this game will stun and astound you.

reviewText: This game, if you want to call it that, was possibly one of the most well written and heart felt stories I have had the pleasure of being a part of. I cannot recommend this enough for the truly captivating tale of love and loss that this game brings to life.  Also, don't be afraid of the tears that are bound to come, you'll feel better in the morning about life, love, hope and what tomorrow may bring.  So tear up, it's good for you.

reviewText:
Note: I received a copy of To The Moon for my birthday!

First off I would like to start by stating that you don't actually have to use your mouse (some people get annoyed), you can use your arrow keys and your space bar (interaction key) and just use your mouse as a guide. Also, this game's graphics isn't the best (pixel art) but I promise it actually grows on you and you will start to like it. Especially because there are some sick illustrations later on.

Positives:
+ Deep storyline (very well thought out, kudos to the Developer's efforts) - you don't actually know what to expect when you first start playing this game; it's much more than you think it is
+ Relatively nice graphics (Pixel Art)
+ Beautiful and fitting music (Situational)
+ Extra minisodes (DLCS)
+ Character development is simply wonderful, and very well done
+ Good excuse to go grab some ice cream as soon as you get to 'Act 3' (I cried a little)
+ Maps aren't too large, but large enough to explore thoroughly and enjoyably especially with the little dialogues or things you pick up
+ Relatively easy puzzles, but not too easy - it also displays the lowest amount of moves needed to complete the puzzle which makes you visualise the outcomes and how to complete it with the least amount of moves. Tip: As soon as it tells you about the diagonal flipping, use it because almost every puzzle afterwards requires it (to achieve least amount of moves)
+ Saving options are very well thought out - automatic saves for important actions and you can also use manual saving
+ There are nice little extras in the game menu where it shows you the items you have and specific 'notes' or interesting things you have found out - this is updated quite frequently and worth your time to check out

Negatives:
- Although I loved the character development and thought it was very well done, I definitely would have liked it more if there was more background information about Johnny's mother. We only know a little about her but I feel like she plays a bigger role than that.
- Puzzles that can get repetitive (it's not too bad)
- Walking speed is quite slow and can get annoying waiting for them to hurry up
- Some larger maps can get tedious - walking around and finding things

Overall:
The main focus of the actual game (storyline) is very beautiful, relatable and enjoyable. It made me cry after 'Act 3' at various scenes (those who have played know what I mean). The way the story is set out seems a bit odd at first, but as you continue on it makes a lot of sense and I feel is the perfect way to lay it out. The ending was simply beautiful and you don't really see it coming - in fact, you don't see many events (plot twists people) happening until it does. There is a little bit of humour, especially with the protagonists and it's a very deep, heartfelt story. Despite the negatives, I would like to say that the postitives definitely outweigh the negatives.

I love stories like these because you don't have to make any serious choices, yet the choices the protagonists make, makes you think about your morals and what you would do in such a situation. I've spent some time considering the many options and the options the protagonists made plus the repurcussions and their situations, and I finally came to the conclusion of what was morally correct. I'm fully content with the ending. I think this game is a lot about the morality of how these people help the man, as well as others. The DLCs do explore the concept of morality and how some people think what they do is immoral.

Score: 9/10
It's not perfect but it's close enough. Definitely worth the full price (and if you like the music, get the soundtracks too) and you get free minisodes (DLCS).

I could go on and on and on... But let me say this: Just play the game, you won't regret it.

reviewText: I have to preface this recommendation by saying that To The Moon isn't really much of a game. It's an interactive story, and a phenomenal one at that. So if you're one of those people who refuse to play interactive story experiences for whatever reason, then you'll probably get nothing out of this.\n\nFor the rest of you, I say strap yourselves in and give it a shot. To The Moon is an emotional journey through a dying man's memories in order to fulfill his last wish of going to the moon. To say more really spoils what makes it so great, but suffice to say I went into this with fairly low expectations (it is an RPG Maker title after all) and came away from it wondering why we haven't had more stories in gaming that were this compelling. I couldn't actually pull myself away from the screen until I'd completed it and left going argh
recommended: I can do nothing but recommend To The Moon. Just know what you're getting into."

reviewText:
I try to review games as I finish them, so I can look back on them later. Weeks, months, years down the road - they help me remember the way a game made me feel, or even the person I was when I was at that particular time.

To the Moon, for some reason, I never reviewed.

Was it because upon completion, I was crying? Reflecting? Contemplating the meaning of life? Experiencing the dreaded feels?

Yeah, probably.

In To The Moon you take control of two doctors/scientists who have been hired by a dying man to grant his last wish - to go the moon. Though it is an odd request, the doctors do not question it. But to get him there, they must piece together his blurred memories, of loss, of love, of his complicated relationship with the love of his life.

It feels almost intrusive to walk through a stranger's most delicate memories, and they invite you to examine your own relationships with the ones you love, flawed and complex as they may be.

Play when you're contemplative, you won't regret it.

That's the most wonderful, the saddest/happiest and the most emotional game I have ever played.
Honestly, its developers are geniuses/saddists here for making such a game using easy to get gamemaking tools.
If you want to take a part in a story that breaks your heart this is a game for you. And you will never look at paper bunnies the same way.

The only glitch is the achievement to gain: for now you have to play on WINDOWS and in ENGLISH to make it happen. At first I played in Polish so it didn't count. I had to change the language in settings to English and replay the last auto-save.

But above that... 4 hours of heart-melting gameplay. It's worth it.

reviewText: You know, day by day, year by year, games will be dated except To The Moon. 5 years later, 10 years later, world can change, technology can evolve but this is still a glorious masterpiece. reviewText:
One of the very best games out there. It has a very strong storyline. This game has everything; mystery and suspense which keeps you on the edge of your seat, emotional moments that'll move you in a way that very few games would ever have. The game has great dialogues consisting of wit and humour. The soundtrack is simply amazing and it changes according to the situations in the game. This is a game that will get you deeply attached to the characters, it will simultaneously break your heart and warm it.

I actually completed the game at a stretch of a few hours. The story had me compelled to play it. It literally made me cry at some points and made me really happy at times. I felt strongly for the characters and it hurt me when something bad happened to them. It would be unbelievable if someone told me he/she didn't shed a  single drop of tear in this. ( The person would probably be heartless )

Damn amazing story with a damn amazing soundtrack, this game is simply the most touching, emotional and beatiful game i've ever played. Would recommend it to everyone and would also recommend to finish it in one stretch :D .

reviewText:
'To the Moon' is intelligent, well written and extremely creative. Two scientists dive into a dying man's mind to alter his memories in order to fulfil his final wish. And yes, the game is just as awesome as it sounds. It has some really cool moments and even though the idea is pretty surreal, it is presented to you in a way that it just sucks you in and the game MAKES you believe it is all actually possible. Not only that, you will feel for these characters. Rarely have there been games that tug on my heart strings the way this game did. Some people seem to finish it in one sitting, take 2 or 3 hours to complete it but it took me 5.2 hours for 1 playthrough from beginning to end. I like to be thorough in my games, especially the story heavy ones that rely on exploration. You will want to take it all in with this game because it is just that good.

It is a very basic point and click game, nothing overly complicated and it doesn't require too much work, there are some minor riddles to solve but in the end, it relies for the most part on its emotion heavy story. The game is story driven and the visuals and soundtrack are both there to intensify the experience. Some songs might come over as repetitive (something actually made fun of within the game itself) but you will hardly notice this because the music is just that good. The graphics are reminiscent of the Super Nintendo era and it works for this game. Finally 'To the Moon' is jam packed with useless nerdy trivia for gamers and people who watch all the good tv shows.

'To the Moon' is dark, atmospheric and you won't leave the game unmarked.

reviewText:
To The Moon has the most moving story I've ever experienced, not just in games, but anywhere.  The game only takes a couple hours to complete, but it is definitely worth it just to experience the story.  The music is beautiful as well and fits perfectly with the story.

The gameplay, however, is at the level where some people may not even call it a game.  While it looks like a classic JRPG, the level of interaction offered is very low.  It mostly consists of walking around to discover what triggers the next cutscene.  At some points the level of interaction offered is almost insulting, with the game giving you control just for a couple seconds to do something easily accomplished during the cutscene.  It's almost as if it's trying to remind you that you're playing a game, not watching the story.  Later in the game, it turns into more of a hidden object game where you solve simple puzzles between chapters which is much more pleasing.

To The Moon is a game that needs to be experienced.  It's too difficult to put it into words, especially without giving any spoilers.

reviewText:
Don't let the store page screenshots fool you, this game is not an RPG despite being made with RPG Maker (The squirrel battle is an ingame joke), It's a linear 16bits-ish adventure game.

Talk to people, look for some items, do a few puzzles, and follow the story. The sad, touching, tear-jerking story. Seriously, if you don't cry you're not human. It's hard to talk about why the game is so great without spoiling the story. The characters have a profound personality rarely seen in a videogame, and they share a deep pure love. The beautiful music just make the experience even more enjoyable.

There's two control schemes, arrow keys or mouse (No WASD for you). Mouse control can be a bit clunky sometimes, with your characters not going at first click where they're supposed to go; playing with a keyboard is faster and more efficient but then you won't have a clue about what things you can interact with.
You can choose from 10 different languages. The game lasts around 4 hours and doesn't really have replay value, but it's worthy. You can also play a free minisode that takes place after the events of the game. It's located on Steam\SteamApps\common\To the Moon\To the Moon\SigCorp - Holiday Special (Bonus Game)

reviewText:
'한 편의 아름다운 소설과 감미로운 음악을 동시에 체감하며 즐길 수 있는 작품'

게임이란 넓은 범주에서 보면 인간이 즐길 수 있는 모든 것을 포함할 것이다. 투 더 문은 이런 넓은 범주에서의 게임에 속한다.

투 더 문을 하면서 느낀 게임의 '장르'적인 방식은 마치 '디어 에스더'와 비슷하다.
유저가 게임을 직접하면서 개입할 수 있는 것은 거의 없으며, 게임적인 요소도 거의 없는 점이 비슷하다.

유저가 할 수 있는 행동은 이동과 단서 모으기 및 퍼즐 맞추기 뿐.
하지만, 이러한 요소 중 단서 모으기 및 퍼즐 맞추기는 절묘하게 스토리적인 '시스템'에 부합해서 어색함이 없다. 다만 이런 게임적 요소도 챕터 1에서 끝나버린다.

이 게임을 하게되면 유저는 4시간 가량되는 플탐동안 감미로운 OST와 감동을 이끌어내는 스토리를 별다른 개입 없이 체험만 하게된다.

게임의 스토리 요소와 OST는 매우 높은 평가와 점수를 줄만하다. 하지만, 어찌보면 그냥 비주얼 노블 마냥 진행되는 게임의 방식에 질리는 유저도 분명 존재할 것이다. 게임인가 소설인가. 그것은 직접 유저들이 판단할 문제지만 어떻게든 이 게임을 구매한 유저들에게 만족감을 준다면 그건 그거대로 좋은 작품이라는 뜻이되지 않을까?

투 더 문 시리즈의 미래를 봤을 때, 앞으로도 후속작들이 이런 방식으로 나올 것이 거의 확실한 듯 해보인다. 여러 떡밥을 해결하기 위해 작가가 스토리를 어떻게 풀어갈지 후속작도 기대가 되는 작품이다.

reviewText:
'Ladies and gentleman, welcome aboard the feels train. Todays destination will be: the Moon!'

Okay let's be honest: the gameplay of 'To the Moon' is quite boring, it's repetitive and often more annoying than entertaining. It's not the typical 'Fighting & Fantasy'-RPG-Maker game but a strictly linear adventure whichsets its focus on the story about an old man and his dying wish. Sure, there are minigames and some 'better' levels, but after the fifth time collecting some memory links to go on to the next level I just thought 'C'mon just skip this, I don't want to do this agai-... great another memory link level'. But I still recommend this game - without any doubts - to everyone who enjoys a good story.

You ask why? It'S true, for me 'To the Moon' is an 'average' game at best, but at the same time it's a fantastic 'movie' with an interesting story backed up by an amazing soundtrack, well-written dialogues, interesting characters and an atmosphere that makes up for many flaws. I really enjoyed the plot and the great dialogues between the characters and you can definitly see how much time the developers used to make every scene create the right emotional situation. And - at least in my case - they succeeded.

reviewText:
This game made me realize that being bigger and having beautiful graphics is not always better.  More than anything else, game developers should strive to give us games that are both memorable and satisfying.  A game that makes you feel and experience something extraordinary.
To the Moon is not gorgeous in terms of graphics.  What it lacks in graphics, it makes up for its interactive story telling.  It lets you take part in a tale that is both hearthwarming and incredibly tragic.
The story immerses you and engages you to fulfill a dying man's (Johnny) last wish to go the moon, by altering his memory and replacing them with alternates ones.
What really made the journey interactive is how you put together bits and pieces of his memory and various highlights of his life and love story with wife (River) in order to progress forward in the story.
You will also be carried away by the games soundtrack, specially its main theme also entitled - To The Moon.  It really enhances your game experience and sets the mood in every game sequence.  The game, however, is relatively short, but the game content is what all that matters to me.  The game's message about life and death and the joys and difficulties we might or have already experienced did struck a chord.  In the end all we have our just cherished memories of our loved ones. The moral of the game is' if we had the chance and the ability to change our past, Will you do it?  Maybe some for me.
I really recommend this to a mature audience or even someone who needs a break from the run and gun games we have in our games library.  Kudos to the game developers for giving us such a wonderful game.  Can't wait for the next installment.

reviewText:
This is a beautiful game made in RPG Maker, but not a RPG at all. It has elements of exploration, story-driven and puzzle, but the main objective seems to be the emotional effect. The game is very successful on enabling that, especially at the ending, because it builds momentum through interaction with “mementos” from various periods of a person’s life. There is a chance you will drop some tears.

This game is also very special to me because it was given as a gift (thank you again for this!), and it made me think about my own life. I like the way the game mixes humor and drama together, and gives you simple puzzles in between story scenes. Also, the game adds a lot of interface innovations to RPG Maker.

My take on some points:

River’s condition looks like some kind of autism, which is very rare on women.

The meaning of the two colored paper rabbit becomes clear at some point: the yellow is the moon and the blue is the sky with the stars. John couldn’t know this, as his memory was messy because of the beta blockers.

The game is somehow based on psychoanalytical arguments, such as: infancy memories are the most important ones. Even when repressed, these memories can affect your conscious decisions.

The “romantic” ending somehow implies that a perfect relationship can only happen in dreams. In the real world you will always have problems.

reviewText:
Absolutely sensational storytelling. Very few games out there succeed in excellent story and character development that attracts and scars players. To The Moon is one of the few that does an outstanding job in not only nailing this, but also leaving a long-lasting impact.

Without revealing too much to those that have yet to play - You assume control of two Doctors – Dr. Neil Watts and Dr. Eva Rosalene – whom work for an agency whose job is to reconstruct certain aspects of dying people's memories and fulfil their deepest wishes before their lights are out; in this case, taking Johnny to the Moon. The reason to which I will not explain in this review, otherwise there would be no point in going through all the emotions this game sets out to deliver. Though you can expect a story filled with excellent dialogue and character development with plenty of unpredictable moments

Gameplay is fairly straight forward and pretty much the same as TWD or any point-and-click game for that matter. There are a few mini-games and puzzles to add that little challenge factor but nothing overly complicated or mind numbing. Everything is straight forward and easy to pick up.

The soundtrack is composed to perfection and aids the storytelling in a very unique way. A great mixture of tracks which change depending on the scenario at hand.

The only aspect that may throw some people off is the fact that there is almost zero replayability, with the average completion time appearing to be anywhere around the 4.5 hour mark. Unless of course certain aspects of the game did not sink in properly the first time and you attempt a second rerun, though this does not bother me at all as it aimed to convey a purpose right from the beginning and was delivered to great satisfaction.

Overall a wonderful game I would very strongly recommend. Do not let the simple graphics fool you! Deep down tears will be shed playing this little blockbuster.

reviewText:
To the Moon is a beautiful game on many levels. The music, sounds, story, artwork, atmosphere, and delivery unlock a cornucopia of raw and powerful emotions that cling to the obvious passion the developers put into it. It's a pretty remarkable journey of closure, one that is amazingly told backwards.

All giddiness aside, the gameplay and user interaction are definite weak spots, although quite easy to overlook. The story also showcases a striking resemblance to movie concepts from Total Recall (memory implants)--not a knock...just saying.

Only a select few indie titles have come close to pulling off the grand gaming experience that To the Moon delivers. It is every little bit a must experience game.

reviewText:
This game. It seems to be one of those typical pretentious indie games at first glance, but by god, this is so much more. Let me get this out of the way first: To the Moon is the game that I cried the most at throughout my whole life.

Now, it doesn't really consist of a lot more than text and accompanying music, but that's way more than enough for immersion into such an amazing story—the plot was absolutely new to me, with no clichés in its integral parts at all. The setting is very similar to, or I'd even dare say borrowed from the movie 'Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind', but it goes way deeper beyond that, to, as far as I know, previously uncharted territories of storytelling. Naturally, because of this, the story was for the most part unpredictable for me; this is what happens when none of your actions really matter and yet the life of someone is depending on them... maybe. I'm really not even sure what to make of this all, I still am in shock after having played through the game and I will need quite some time to completely process what I've seen.

Above all this, the game has an unbelievably great soundtrack that meshes with the story so well that you'll cry even more just because of the musical score. There's even some really humorous moments in the game, that include but are not limited to: poking fun at those pretentious indie games I mentioned above, breaking the fourth wall, making hilarious puns, having absolutely unexpected moments, and so on. There's clearly tons of attention paid to every detail of the game, having a masterfully crafted experience.

The negatives: not much, really. The author clearly doesn't have the best technical background, so you'll be stuck playing at a weird resolution no matter what, but it doesn't take a lot to get used to.

I'm still real close to crying. ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
To The Moon is an emotional journey, one that I haven't really ever experienced in games. It's a game with RPG Maker graphics so it looks simple, but its strength lies in its storytelling.

The way the story is told is done in a way that will keep you (mostly) interested during the entire experience. While it lasts only 4 hours or so, there's very little gameplay involved (there's even a somewhat frustrating part near the end).

Even though the game lacks in the graphics department, it makes up for it by its amazing soundtrack. I enjoyed it so much that I even bought it seperately afterwards.

Keep an open mind, ignore the graphics and just enjoy the ride.
A must own !

[Rating: 83/100]

reviewText:
To the Moon is an adventure game/bordering on visual novel which uses 16-bit era RPG-style graphics to communicate its story. In it, two doctors use a device which allows them to travel through a man's memories, altering them in such a way that in his coma state it allows him to dream that he has lived the life which would have resulted from those alterations.

The story is the important factor of this game, so I'll refrain from saying any further due to spoilers. It's an excellent story although the writing can be a little mediocre in spots. I'd recommend finishing the game in one or two sittings to get the full experience, but that is not mandatory by any means.

For those who enjoy narrative-driven games, this is a must purchase. However, it might be worthwhile to wait for a sale of some sort.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Two parts Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, one part Inception, some really charming visuals and an extremely memorable and beautiful soundtrack and you've got To The Moon.

You take control of two scientists who are part of an organization specializing in altering the unfulfilled memories of dying patients in order to help ease their passing. They crash their car on the way to their latest patient, who wants to believe he went to the moon before he dies, and saying much more than that would begin to ruin the premise, but rest assured it is a GREAT premise. Some very good narrative reveals, great character dialogue (for the most part, details on that later), and a story that you'd have to have a heart of stone not to appreciate on some level. I can admit that I'm a bit of a curmudgeon when it comes to games trying to touch my heart, but with the story, visuals and music I couldn't help but give myself over to the experience during a few particularly beautiful sequences.

As far as gameplay goes, there really isn't much to speak of outside of hunting for clues in the levels, solving the picture puzzle at the end of each memory and a few scarce, optional minigames. It's also worth noting that it's a very short game, able to be finished in around 4-5 hours. That being said, it's one of those games I plan on going back to play every couple years, and it's not a very expensive game, either.

My only real complaints are that the game can be broken fairly easily (Moving through solid environments, walking through cars, I even encountered a glitch early on with the log jumping mechanic that nearly forced me to delete my save and start over) and the dialogue between the scientists can be extremely poorly timed and downright obnoxious and can occassionaly ruin otherwise very touching moments. I understand the need for comic relief in a game like this, but screaming HULK SMASH!!" and "HADOUKEN!" during emotional moments isn't the way to do it.

Even so
date: it's still a very enjoyable game that you should definitely play if you get the chance. I wouldn't suggest picking it up for more than a few bucks if you're not the type to replay a game periodically as it is
hoursPlayed: only about 4-5 hours long. It's in a bundle right now and it goes on sale very cheaply from time to time

reviewText:
At first glance, To the Moon may simply look like another of those retro-coated adventures or RPGs that go dime a dozen these days. Granted, it is technically a text-driven, point-n-click adventure with a few minigames here and there. Yet when experienced in its entirety, it becomes clear that it is much more than that.

Fresh from credits rolling, I can say that it's one of the best stories I've ever been told through the medium of video games. It's a unique, humane piece, unlike any I've come to experience; so elaborately woven together, so well-written and touching with flawless pacing all-around that I could have easily enjoyed it as a book if the author, Kan Gao, had chosen to tell it so. Better yet, this superb script is accompanied by an exquisite audio-visual package that enriches the adventure greatly. The result of the amalgamation of these expertly crafted elements was an experience so rich that I couldn't help myself going through it in a single session, caring about every single one of its small cast of characters and wondering what would I uncover about them next all the way. Needless to say, I found myself being amazed from scene to scene, as the 'game' was delivering everything to be expected from a true work of art in spades.

The fact that this kind of an experience is not coming from of a first-tier developer but born from the minds and crafted in the hands of a small group of individuals with a small budget is only a nod to their talent. I must admit that I wasn't expecting such a fine-tuned creation with this much of an impact when I first booted the game. But here I am, after a five-hour rollercoaster of emotions, feeling all the more human thanks to this excellent work of art disguised as a game.

My advice, don't lose any more time reading about To the Moon. Get it, live through it and see if it doesn't take a place among your most precious gaming memories, 'cause it surely got itself one of the best for me.

reviewText:
People give excellent games a 10/10 and maybe half of them deserve it, but To The Moon has a brilliant story that needs to be experienced by everyone and their grandmother.  There's really nothing quite like it, and the fact that it's able to convey such a brilliant story WITHOUT voice acting and using 16-bit graphics is genius in itself.

I would put this in the same calibur as a Half Life, Super Mario 64, Warcraft 3, type of level even though there really isn't any gameplay.  I would put it above Life Is Strange and Grim Fandango as well, which were my favorite interactive-story type of games before I played this.  Yes, it's THAT freaking good!

11/10

reviewText: It is extremely rare to find a work of art as brilliant as To the Moon. This visual novel revolves around Johnny Wyles, a dying man who has lived a sad, and unfulfilling life. Johnny's dying wish is to go to the moon, though he doesn't know why. To make this wish a reality, he enlists Dr. Eva Rosaline and Dr. Neil Watts of Sigmund Corp. who are determined to send Johnny to the moon one way or another.\n\nTo the Moon has an incredible story, fantastic artwork, and an absolutely beautiful soundtrack. It evokes a variety of emotions, and contains plenty of comic relief. I would absolutely recommend To the Moon for any casual gamers, particularly those who love visual novels.

reviewText: It would be hard for me to describe how, Wonderful this game really is. Never played too many indie games before, but this one is the best of all of them. The story is no doubt the strongest point in the game, which is beautifully directed and covers emotion, love, humour and sadness of human life, in a very nice way, The characters in the game are very memorable . And the soundtrack is so wonderful and memorable, the music still plays inside my head and its very pleasant to hear it, again and again. Even the art is great, nothing to complain, even there were a few things like key customization which would been nice, but it didnt bother me, and can easily be ignored and This game is filled with so much emotion that I almost cried towards the end!  Overall this game is recommended for everyone, you just can't avoid this masterpiece, it would be a shame to do so.. ! 10/10.

reviewText:
A really beautiful game, it does rarely find a work as brilliant as this point & click. It has fantastic artwork, great characters and the soundtrack does amazingly fit each situation.

It is incredibly well written with a lot of emotional aspects, there are moments that you will find yourself laughing at the humor but also saddened by it touching story making you to cry. It's an incredibly touching experience.

reviewText: To The Moon is everything I want in a game,  Sure, it has little gameplay and is more interactive story than really a game, but this it handles perfectly. It is one of the rare games that made me laugh, cry and feel with the characters on screen, which not many games manage to do nowadays. The story within is very human, touching, and well handled in its build up till its very tear-inducing conclusion. It is a story about people, about love and loss, and every fine nuance in between. Honestly, I can't hardly recall any game --or media in general -- which moved me to this extent like it did. Yes, it is limited in its graphics, being an RPG-Maker game, though it does use it in a very charming and heartwarming way, accompanied by beautiful music extra composed for the game.\n\nTo say more would mean to spoil it, so let me conclude in saying that playing To The Moon was a very unique and great experience, and I'm thankful for having made it.

reviewText:
Easily worth the purchase while it is on sale (I actually got this in a Humble Bundle quite sometime ago and only just got around to playing it), but even at full price; I wouldn't regret buying it for a second. I decided to start playing this last night, big mistake on my part, as I could not stop!

Even after I finished the game, I just HAD to play the free DLC episodes, set in the protagonists’ workplace. Which were short even compared to the main game, but were enjoyable all the same, and slightly creepy~but enough about those.

To The Moon is a great game, it made me tear up a bit with how emotional it gets, it also made me laugh at times. There's a decent amount of humour, mostly in the form of Dr Neil Watt's shenanigans and dialogue, and it takes the edge off the largely sad narrative. That said, the story is not all doom and gloom, it may even surprise you--it did me.

I now eagerly await this game's true sequel, while I ponder the strange goings on of the mini episodes, hmm~

Another example of why a videogame doesn't need top-notch graphics to be enjoyable.

reviewText: Background: dislike Nintendo RPG" art
date:
love point n clicks. Heard good things about the game.

The Good:
* Great sound and atmosphere for a game with such limited animation
* Outstanding story with humour
recommended:
sadness and joy
* Fun but not difficult mini game puzzles
* First rate dialogue with very natural characters and reactions
* Superb use of memories in the latter parts
* Characters have depth and there's surprising subtly included
* Leaves you wanting more and lots of hints at unexplored concepts

The Bad:
* Bland but well crafted '8bit' art
* Very clunky mouse movement and hit n miss hotspots
* Clunky speech skipping that stopped working in chapter 3 for me
* Short and little to no immediate replay value
* Horse riding section is confusingly under explained

Impressions: Much like 'Gone Home' this is a story being unfolded as you move and click. It tugs the heartstrings and plays with your emotions but not in a cynical way that left me tearful and sorely impressed at how well delivered the story was. The high concept plot and natural dialogue raise the game well above it's underwhelming artwork and poor hotspot/movement detection and pathing.

Recommended for: People with a heart and a soul for a well told story. Requires pixel hunting and plenty of reading.

Conclusion: 8/10. Story of the year that will stay with you for a long time."

reviewText:
Short story-rich 2D retro adventure with great atmosphere, interesting plot, heartbreaking moments & boring longueurs
What I liked
Deep atmosphere for a 2D adventure
Interesting plot, interesting characters, lovely heartbreaking love story
Decent 2D pixel graphics from the age of Secret of Mana / Chrono Trigger
Short game, perfect for one session the weekend or in the evening after work
100% achievements after first playthrough (around 3,5 hours)
What I didn't like
Unnecessary long dialogues
Street language does not really fit the atmosphere
Humour is not mine
Controls with mouse and keyboard are clunky
Repetitive in the middle of the game
Zero replay-value
Recommended for what it is: a short lovely 2D game. You should buy it on sale for not more than 5 EUR
