reviewText:
English Version:
Given that I was not convinced about this game's quality, I wanted to try It, and I have to say that I understimated It because of its low price.

Is a 2D adventure game with apparently very simple dynamics, but It has a lot to offer to the players. The protagonist, a man with the only wish of reaching the moon, seemingly inexplicable, is dying; so he asks over Doctoress Eva Rosalene and Neil Watts, who belong to the sigmund Agency of Life Generation, in the attempt of reaching his very last wish through artificially implanted memories. However, as the game progresses, the plot thickens and the introspection and the past of the poor elderly protagonist, Johnny Wyles, begins to excite the minds even colder.

The graphics do not excell but they offer simple and different scenarios. The plot, at least to me, is very reminiscent of Inception (for those who saw it), even if we are talking about memories and not dreams. Johnny and his poor wife are deeply characterized, so much that the gamers are made aware about the wife's health condition, which is not so rare in today's reality. The soundtracks are very impressive, and in any case always suited to the circumstances in which they find themselves. The gameplay is very simple, but the depth of the story manages to entertain the gamer to everyone for the duration (albeit brief) of the game. Yes, the game, unfortunately, is short-lived, but nevertheless It's an experience recommended to all.

Do not be fooled by the low price, as It previously happened to me: It's a MUST HAVE in your Steam Library

Italian Version:
Sono venuta in possesso di questo gioco grazie al consiglio di un amico, che già lo possedeva. Non convinta dell'eccellenza di tale titolo, ho voluto provarlo, e devo dire di averlo sottovalutato per via del prezzo basso.

To the moon è un'avventura grafica in 2d che si presenta come un gioco dalle dinamiche molto semplici che tuttavia ha molto da offrire ai giocatori.  Il protagonista, un uomo con il solo scopo di raggiungere la luna, apparentemente inspiegabile, è in fin di vita; così convoca nella sua abitazione sopra una scogliera i dottor Eva Rosalene e Neil Watts, appartenenti alla Sigmund Agency Of Life Generation, intento a raggiungere il suo ultimo desiderio attraverso l'impianto di ricordi artificiali. Tuttavia, man mano che il gioco avanza, la trama si infittisce e l'introspezione ed il passato del povero anziano protagonista, Johnny Wyles, inizia ad emozionare anche le menti più fredde.

La grafica, pur non eccellendo, offre scenari diversificati e semplici. La trama, almeno a me, ricorda molto Inception (per chi l'ha visto), anche se qui si parla di ricordi e non di sogni. La caratterizzazione di Jhonny e della sua povera moglie è ben approfondita, tanto da sensibilizzare la gente sulla condizione di quest'ultima, che non è così tanto rara nella realtà d'oggi. Le colonne sonore sono molto suggestive, ed in ogni caso sempre adatte al contesto nelle quali si trovano. Il gameplay è molto semplice, tuttavia la profondità della storia riesce ad intrattenere il videogiocatore allo schermo per tutta la durata (seppur breve) del gioco. Ebbene sì, il gioco, purtroppo, è poco longevo, ma tuttavia è un'esperienza consigliabile a tutti.

Non fatevi ingannare dal prezzo basso, com'è successo a me, è un MUST HAVE in libreria.

reviewText:
To the Moon is one of the most touching games I've played in years. With such a wonderfully written storyline riddled with humerous and nostalgic references alike, TtM really shines with it's interpretation of memories. When I played the first few moments I expected an interesting Sci-Fi interpretation of how the mind works, which was delivered promptly, but I hadn't expected how utterly mind-blowing of a level it would reveal itself to land on.

Flawlessly implementing emotional story-telling, point-and-click gameplay, and an ocean of character progression, TtM leaves you on the edge of your seat, yearning for the next act of the three installments. I haven't felt the pressure of tears behind my eyes as a result from a game since Kingdom Hearts and Shadow of the Colossus were released in 2002 and 2005 respectively. Had this game been released during my preadolescence, it would've been just as impacting on my development as those two games were. In all honesty, even at this stage of my life, I found this game to be rather impacting, as well as eye opening on many levels.

To the Moon is a game I'd recommend for all ages, as a casual point-and-click story driven adventure RPG, it has so much to offer to every generation. Undoubtedly worth the extra 'dough' for the heart-string-pulling soundtrack as well, especially considering that 50% of the bandcamp proceeds go towards charities.

10/10, will play again.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I have trouble discussing To the Moon. It's not that there's nothing to talk about, actually it's the opposite. The problem is that basically there are spoilers everywhere. I'm gonna tread very carefully. The game is about two doctors: Neil Watts, and Eva Rosalene. However, they are not medical doctors. Their job is to visit the dying, and use special technology to alter their memories to include their final, last wish so they can die happy. Their patient is Johnny Wyles, an elderly man who wants to go to the moon. Here's the kicker, he doesn't know why. Understanding the motivation for a dream is essential in altering the memories for the person owning said dream. This is so fitting the memory in the person's life becomes much simpler. I'm not gonna go an inch farther in terms of discussing the story, it's for your own good.\nThe gameplay is hardly there, it's pretty much a full on visual novel. However, traversing Wyles' memories involves picking up memory links that let the two doctors piece what they know together. You travel back connecting the memory links with a certain memento per memory period. You then complete a very simple puzzle to add in a little bit of player input. But overall you are really just watching a movie.\nBecause I'm choosing to talk about almost nothing, I'm gonna have to cut this short. This game has made a reputation for itself as the home of genuine feels, and I agree. Not only is this game funny, but it is also serious and realistic. This has been said many times before, but it makes my point, You don't need polygons to make people." And that is true. It's been a long time since I genuinely cared about the characters I'm controlling and learning about. If you're not convinced
hoursPlayed: please risk a few dollars to get this game. It's worth a risk."

reviewText:
To the Moon is one of the most touching games I've played in years. With such a wonderfully written storyline riddled with humerous and nostalgic references alike, TtM really shines with it's interpretation of memories. When I played the first few moments I expected an interesting Sci-Fi interpretation of how the mind works, which was delivered promptly, but I hadn't expected how utterly mind-blowing of a level it would reveal itself to land on.

Flawlessly implementing emotional story-telling, point-and-click gameplay, and an ocean of character progression, TtM leaves you on the edge of your seat, yearning for the next act of the three installments. I haven't felt the pressure of tears behind my eyes as a result from a game since Kingdom Hearts and Shadow of the Colossus were released in 2002 and 2005 respectively. Had this game been released during my preadolescence, it would've been just as impacting on my development as those two games were. In all honesty, even at this stage of my life, I found this game to be rather impacting, as well as eye opening on many levels.

To the Moon is a game I'd recommend for all ages, as a casual point-and-click story driven adventure RPG, it has so much to offer to every generation. Undoubtedly worth the extra 'dough' for the heart-string-pulling soundtrack as well, especially considering that 50% of the bandcamp proceeds go towards charities.

10/10, will play again.

reviewText:
I had a very emotional reaction. It seems like I wasn't alone. I learned something about myself. And in some ways it helped me deal with some trauma from my past.

Would I, laying on my deathbed wish to erase trauma from my past? Knowing that before these thoughts pass through my head I would forget everything that really did happen? I have no idea. I used to think, of course I would. If I could think that I went to the moon. Even if I didn't. Sure I would. But, after beating the game. Although I helped Johnny fulfill his wish. I feel a bit empty. I'd love to go into why I feel empty. But I think I'd be treading upon spoilers.

This is a game about a story. Not a game about gameplay. Not a game about competition. This is a game about a story. An experience. Even though I bought this game for only $1.99 I would, and probably will buy it for $9.99 for a friend.

I feel like everyone should have the option of experiencing a story as moving as this. This is games as art.

reviewText:
It is rare that I come across a game so charming and with such a stellar story; To The Moon is both excellently written and superbly executed, and I feel like the events of this game will stay with me for years to come.

Being a huge fan of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, I purchased this game simply because of the parallels I had heard about, and I was not disappointed. As I played, every new discovery left me compelled to uncover more and to find out about the old man's life. At times the dialogue can be a bit silly, but it's much needed comedic relief within a setting that otherwise jumps from tearjerking to heartwarming.

The gamplay is extremely basic, and whilst it is more present than any gameplay in Gone Home, for example, I would still put this in the interactive novel" genre as at its core it is simply a story you are uncovering. There are occasionally small puzzles to jump between memories
date: but I personally found that these became tedious fast and I feel the game would be better without. They do
hoursPlayed: add a little more pacing to the plot and give you some time to think about what you may find next.\n\nTo The Moon is definitely worth buying
voteText: I can't imagine anyone being disappointed by such a rollercoaster ride. I am extremely excited to see what Freebird release next!"

reviewText: I have played To The Moon all the way through, and I cannot express how touching and unique this game and story is. While it hasn't combat like traditional games in this genre, it more than makes up for it in storytelling and small puzzles. It doesn't have any replay value, but I highly suggest catching it on a sale if you are a sucker for a good story.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Regret. Indecision. Joy. Sorrow. Indignation. Anger. Helplessness. To The Moon can and will unrelentingly tug at your heartstrings. It will bring you to the fullest extent of each and every single emotion listed, woven together by the most hauntingly beautiful piano music in the background.

The graphics, though simple, will form images that will stay in your mind - and heart - for a very long time. The story seems simple but goes to so many complex details as the game unfolds them delicately, just at the right moments. I enjoyed every bit of it, from the tear-inducing plot (so much onions) to the little bits of comic banter, whether in exploring Johnny's world or playing the occasional mini-game.

I must concede that the *only* flaw is that there's little replayability value; after all, it is a story-game. But what you get in the 4-5 hours of completing is a wonderful and emotional experience that forces you to look deep inside you. What do you want most in life? What would you pay for it? From thoughts on society and legal obligations, to forced self-reflection on your own goals and dreams, this game has it all.

In summary, do I recommend it? I cannot assent more wholeheartedly - it's the first game that affected me so much that I actually just *had* to write this review. I had received this as part of a bundle; but on hindsight, I would have been willing to pay full price. You have to get it on sale, or grab whichever bundle it appears in. Because it's just that good. Add to cart, process, install and grab a good pair of headphones for an amazingly immersive experience.

reviewText: Easily among my top 10 greatest games of all time. This game doesn't have a whole lot of gameplay but it brings a spectacular story that everyone should check out. The game's plot is all about people who can go into the minds of a dying person and change their memories to make them think that they achieved their dream to help them die happy. The rest of the story you should experience for yourself. The game has a spectacular soundtrack suiting the mood the entire time and I sat down and played this game all in one sitting because the story was just that good. The gameplay is simple point and click to find things and the game will last you from 3-6 hours depending on how much you explore and how fast you are at reading. I recommend this experience strongly to anyone looking for something new, amazing, interesting, and touching (many people have been known to cry during this game). 99/100

reviewText:
This is not a game. It's an interactive story where clicking is required to progress from scene to scene and from dialog to dialog.  The fact that from times to times some ridiculously easy puzzles have to be solved in order to progress doesn't exactly make it a game. There's nothing challenging about it.

Anyway, its best part is the story. It's a complex story that treats matters of life and death in such way that it gets to be felt quite close and personal. I completely don't recommend this to depressive people. I was on the verge of busting into tears several times throughout its duration. The story is great, very touching and impactful. It's hard to speak about it without spoiling it, but I guess I could say it somehow reminds of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, the movie, but only in just a few aspects.

Other than the story (but damn, what a story!...), there was nothing I liked about how To the moon" presented itself to me. The soundtrack supports the story pretty well

reviewText: I have trouble discussing To the Moon. It's not that there's nothing to talk about, actually it's the opposite. The problem is that basically there are spoilers everywhere. I'm gonna tread very carefully. The game is about two doctors: Neil Watts, and Eva Rosalene. However, they are not medical doctors. Their job is to visit the dying, and use special technology to alter their memories to include their final, last wish so they can die happy. Their patient is Johnny Wyles, an elderly man who wants to go to the moon. Here's the kicker, he doesn't know why. Understanding the motivation for a dream is essential in altering the memories for the person owning said dream. This is so fitting the memory in the person's life becomes much simpler. I'm not gonna go an inch farther in terms of discussing the story, it's for your own good.\nThe gameplay is hardly there, it's pretty much a full on visual novel. However, traversing Wyles' memories involves picking up memory links that let the two doctors piece what they know together. You travel back connecting the memory links with a certain memento per memory period. You then complete a very simple puzzle to add in a little bit of player input. But overall you are really just watching a movie.\nBecause I'm choosing to talk about almost nothing, I'm gonna have to cut this short. This game has made a reputation for itself as the home of genuine feels, and I agree. Not only is this game funny, but it is also serious and realistic. This has been said many times before, but it makes my point, You don't need polygons to make people." And that is true. It's been a long time since I genuinely cared about the characters I'm controlling and learning about. If you're not convinced
hoursPlayed: please risk a few dollars to get this game. It's worth a risk."

reviewText:
Beautiful, emotional storytelling. It's a story first, and a point and click game second. The game is simply the medium. It's funny, serious, dark and hopeful all at once. A simple concept experienced masterfully, games don't normally affect me but this one struck a chord. The soundtrack is only a couple of very basic tracks, but it is hauntingly beautiful, and deserving of the pickup. In many ways, this game is like a movie experience with the added benefit of your own input and interaction. Visually, it's retro look gives it charm, and it's impressive how much emotion can be conveyed with pixelated animation.

You take the role of a pair of specialists who enter peoples memories, specifically dying people, to generate an experience from them that they express as a dying wish. In a style reminiscent of Inception they dive into the life of John, to fulfill his wish to go To The Moon. They have great chemistry, with fantastic pop culture references and lots of one liners. The story they discover is touched with meaning and emotion. I can't say what makes this game so great without revealing anything that happens, but it brought me to bittersweet tears.

I bought this on a whim, a whim I now very greatful for. It's a truly enriching game, and it will make you cry.

reviewText:
AUDIO: Heart-felt                                                    AESTHETIC: Stock
MEMORABILITY: Great                                           WORTH: Discount

PROS: Story is exceptional, and told creatively. OST is wonderful, worth a download if you can appreciate solo piano. The world is very interesting; it would be great to see more episodes following different people. The game is easy to control and understand.

CONS: Doctor Watts is a major atmosphere-ruiner. I'm assuming his more obnoxious lines were shoehorned in when it appeared the game was a bit too dramatic, but his meme-rife comedic" relief is very unwelcomed. Much of the graphics are stock.

OVERALL:  To The Moon is a touching endeavor and worth 2-3 hours of your time. The short total playtime and stock graphics may not make it worth its full asking price
date: but Freebird Games can make a hell of a story that's proof that the video game medium can tell tear-jerkers.\n\nSCORE: 7/10"

reviewText:
A BEAUTIFUL FAIRY TALE
Short Review:

Do not be fooled by the mundane name of the game, i wouldnt call it a game, rather a surreal expeience that kept me awake,thinking and i finished the game in 1 go.

The Story is has a very tight and neatly conceptualized plot(executed very well,may i add) that guides the game to a smooth victorious and beautiful finish. The attention to the small things in the plot is what makes it even more convincing.

The main characters Eva and Neil have great chem together,loved the emotional rollercoaster that pans out through the game, the gameplay is fairly linear, but then again it was'nt meant to tense you out.
The music is fairly repeatitive but its worth listening to.

In the End,all i have to say is,while some of us rarely get time to play games,and hence we become really picky about the ones we spend time on, Let me tell you, THIS IS WELL WORTH YOUR TIME.

Free DLCs tooo....yay. 12/10
Here's to hoping this becomes the script for Inception 2.0 :)

reviewText:
Only minor technical issues. Lowres assets (640x480), main menu cursor hover detection is bit wonky, no windowed fullscreen (makes writing a review difficult when each alt-tab takes a couple of seconds), Options menu with F1 - had to figure that out. Sometimes the music is freaking loud compared to the sound effects. Taking screenshots difficult, because no Steam Overlay. External tool gives mostly white frame, needs cutting.
Minor tedium sometimes in that you can't click-hold to move, combined with the fact that while left and right image edge is sharp, top and bottom are faded out.

Had a little difficulty in one glitchy scene figuring out what to do (had to consult the forums). Might just have been the reloading that eventually made it work; not sure.

Unskippable launch sequence, but in this game I can understand it's intended to quickly get you back into the mood of the game. And the game is short enough that this won't be a bother.

The frequently reoccuring minigame introduces a little change to the gameplay, probably made to give some more interaction, even if it's a cheap trick for gving a rewarding feeling when the story itself isn't sufficient. (It would have been though. And finding the pieces for the memento is no challenge anyway.)
It's OK though. You're basically executing the protagonists' job, and that's not just all-awesome, but also involves routine. This makes the experience more immersive.

At first, I was worried the RPG-Makeresque character art style would interfere with the serious style of the story, but that turned out to be no problem. Didn't even need getting used to. (Probably because the character art style is consistently the same throughout the game.)

The story has depth and several more and less philosophical aspects worthy of pondering on. Generally not an entirely original theme, but unique in detail. I actually find the writing quite mature and natural. Whatever people complain about in reviews regarding the writing, it must be specifically personal distaste.
There might be details to the story though that are worth examining for plot holes. And there's a certain more or less surprising twist that was almost ignored by the story progression, which left me a little confused.

If you appreciate beautiful and touching as well as skillful storytelling and would like to experience it with minimal energy investment needed (I myself wasn't very motivated or energetic when playing it, but I'm usually quite thoughtful), then it's definitely a recommendation. Better than watching it as a four-hours movie would have been. In game format, you can occasionally drift off into your own thoughts without freezing the pace, and dialogue speed is in your control, too. So a game is a nice format for this kind of story.

The mini-episode DLCs are as thoughtful and entertaining as the main story.


P.S.: This game is unsatisfying for achievement-hunters, yet very satisfying for completionists. ;-)



UPDATE: After seeing a screenshot on the shop page that I didn't encounter during my playthrough, I realize I should probably try a second one with choosing the other character of the duo. It's a nice touch that you can give at least parts of the playthrough a somewhat more drama or comedy spin based on choices you make. It's not fully linear.

reviewText:
To the Moon is a heart-rending tale of dreams, memories, and knowing that love is malleable, capable of taking forms of true beauty, when worked by the right soul. It is my firm belief that you would enjoy To the Moon, so let me sell you further.

Part 1: The Story

The story starts off with two scientist-type fellows known as Dr. Neil Watts and Dr. Eva Rosalene, employees of a mysterious corporation known as Sigmund Corp. They are specifically tasked with providing the elderly and sick with fulfilling lives before they die, by using the means of a certain memory-altering dream machine that allows them to rewrite their client's memory to fit their ordered specifications. Their client, an old, withering man known only by the name Johnny, has enlisted the help of these two scientists. His request, to become an astronaut and fly high into the sky, to reach the outer edge of the world and engage in a long-awaited rendezvous with the moon. Things go routine for a good while, until it appears that something is very wrong with Johnny's memory. Segmented and heavily disjointed, the mind of the elderly man seems to only connect via a single thread, memories of his deceased wife, River. You'll find along the way that she holds major significance to Johnny, much more than could be originally thought, but I'll leave the satisfaction to you.

Part 2: Gameplay

Surely no game is great without some equally complementing gameplay. Whilst travelling through this cavalcade of emotions and memories, you'll have to deal with searching the man's memories and finding items that can link each piece together, like a grand cranium jigsaw puzzle. Mementos will be scattered about for you to interact and find, and engaging in absorbing the story from each memory is a must if you are to succeed. You'll have to go through some light puzzle elements in order to gain access to the linking power of the mementos, but it's nothing a little brain power can't fix. And even with all this brainiac gameplay, there are indeed moments of action. Remember that squirrel you narrowly dodged on the road? Well, I won't say much, but I can say that you surely haven't seen the last of him. You'll need to have a fighter's spirit, but keeping a shoe handy is about the same.

Part 3: The Lesson

The game holds with it not only what you can gather from surface value, but it also carries underneath it a plethora of teachings and meanings. Now nothing I say here is set in stone, as you take what you will from the experience, but what I've collected from the game is as follows: One of the hardest things to do is to do nothing at all, that sometimes love will find us no matter where we are, and that strangers we meet can be the most interesting people we will ever get to know. These certainly aren't the only lessons to be drawn from this wonderful game, interpretation is a most beautiful thing. I leave the gorgeously complex teachings of this game to you to find, as making your own connections is supremely satisfying, and I'd be nobody to deny you the pleasure.

Overview

This game is definitely worth the priced listed. A fine game with charming graphics, a beautiful story, and a heart-rending conclusion that will leave you fully satisfied with your purchase. With the characters very fleshed out and unique, alongside the worlds" you'd be visiting
date: not to mention the beautiful OST that'll be accompanying you
recommended: I'd give it a most well-deserved 9/10. Buy this game
hoursPlayed: love this game

reviewText:
Beautiful, emotional storytelling. It's a story first, and a point and click game second. The game is simply the medium. It's funny, serious, dark and hopeful all at once. A simple concept experienced masterfully, games don't normally affect me but this one struck a chord. The soundtrack is only a couple of very basic tracks, but it is hauntingly beautiful, and deserving of the pickup. In many ways, this game is like a movie experience with the added benefit of your own input and interaction. Visually, it's retro look gives it charm, and it's impressive how much emotion can be conveyed with pixelated animation.

You take the role of a pair of specialists who enter peoples memories, specifically dying people, to generate an experience from them that they express as a dying wish. In a style reminiscent of Inception they dive into the life of John, to fulfill his wish to go To The Moon. They have great chemistry, with fantastic pop culture references and lots of one liners. The story they discover is touched with meaning and emotion. I can't say what makes this game so great without revealing anything that happens, but it brought me to bittersweet tears.

I bought this on a whim, a whim I now very greatful for. It's a truly enriching game, and it will make you cry.

reviewText:
Don't judge a game by it's cover. Or in this case, it's engine. You might think that a game made in RPG Maker isn't worth your time. Well, in this case you're wrong. Or at least that depends what you're looking for.

'To the Moon' does a lot of things right, but most important and memorable it its writing and atmosphere. Long story short, the game is about exploring a dying man's memories to grant him a final wish. What you get is an emotional ride with both ups and downs, mostly the latter. But the game is all about its story and it's perfectly executed.

But if you're looking for an RPG, you're looking in the wrong place. The game has no sort of choice-and-consequence system, no fighting (except for one battle, but I won't spoil that!) or nothing that would make this rank as an RPG. The game will always be the same, so there's not much replay value to it.

So if you're looking for a game with a great story to invest a few hours into, look no further. Freebird Games will prove to you that you don't need to be a AAA-studio to make an enjoyable and memorable gaming experience.

reviewText:
I don't really know how to describe this game, other than to say it's an interactive story with some light gameplay in it. However, I don't mean that in a bad way, as it's a very good format to tell a story.

The story follows two doctors working in a company that grants its clients (who are all people on their deathbeds) a last wish of sorts before they die: they rewrite their memories so they can accomplish whatever they dreamed of; in the case of the game, the client is a man who always dreamed of going to the Moon, hence the title of the game. The story is very good, and emotional; and I'd say the game it's worth it for the story alone. Still, I'd make a disservice to the devs, as they managed to craft a very good game not only storywise, but in aesthethics and overall tone. The traditional RPG style fits the game pretty well, and the soundtrack is very good as well.

As far as gameplay goes, as I said, it has light gameplay; there won't be a lot of fighting or anything like that; only going around interacting with certain objects, and having dialogue with different NPCs. Even then, it's entertaining enough, and the gameplay works to enhance the story.

After the main story, there's two extra DLC chapters (which can be downloaded for free), which show a bit more of the company the doctors work for; and it's set during Christmas, after the events of the main game. The tone remains somewhat similar to that of the main game, although there's a few interesting twists (particularly in the second chapter).

Well, I don't think I can say much more about this game, other than I recommend it.

reviewText: What can I say? When I first booted up To the Moon I was expecting an RPG in the likes of final fantasy (based on the graphics). Instead what I got was a gripping and emotional rollercoaster ride filled with joy, love and loss. The characters have realistic personalities and funny at times which makes it easier to connect to them. The soundtrack is superb and does a marvelous job of setting the mood during gameplay. Story is the main attraction here, taking elements from Pixar's 'UP' as inspiration for the mature themes presented. The only fault is the gameplay, which involves moving around and doing simple puzzles. However since the focus of this game isn't the gameplay, it's not a major  issue (it's more like an interactive visual novel).\n\nI highly recommend everyone to play this game or at least have a go. It's a story you won't forget.

reviewText:
To The MoonFreebird Games
Average playtime: 4.0 hours (this is a review account)

When this world is no more, the moon is all we'll see
And I'll ask you to fly away with me.

To The Moon is one of the very few games that I confidently recommend to all of my friends, no matter what genre they like or what games they play. Don't let the graphics and engine fool you, this is one of few hidden and underrated RPG Maker gems that exist. The amazing and immersive story plus the music (my favorite video game soundtrack of all time, currently) and concept have engaged me to the point that when the game finally ended, I found my face drenched and myself in need of a box of tissues and a good hug. However, the engine's shortcomings are the really only negatives: the game only runs in an low resolution and the game doesn't support the Steam Overlay. However, the positives definitely outweigh the negatives.

TL;DRPros: Amazing story, great music composition, made me feel something at the end
Cons: Engine limitations (low resolution, no Steam overlay), straight outta RPG Maker
Overall score: 9/10
Should I buy this: Yes, if you are a homo sapien with a pulse and can/want to take a good feel

reviewText:
Beautiful.
Before going in-depth with my review for the game, I want to sum it up with that one word alone:  Beautiful.

Upon purchasing the game, I didn't know what I was getting myself into. Sure, I've heard praises about it some time ago and it was on sale recently for a very reasonable price. So, I bought the game along with its soundtrack bundled in without any idea what to truly expect. And after just finishing the game recently, I can safely say that what I got was an experience worth every penny.

Keyword: experience".

I'll start off by discussing what I think is the main problem that people seem to have for the game (based on the negative Steam reviews).
This game is labeled as an "Indie Adventure Role Playing Game". It was also designed through the RPG Maker XP engine. So it is of no surprise that people expect at least a bit of RPG Maker gameplay elements that are typically found elsewhere. But this game doesn't have that. In fact
recommended: this game doesn't have much else in terms of 'gameplay'.\n\nAnd therein lies the problem. It's hard to call it a 'game' when it barely has any gameplay elements to it. Heck
hoursPlayed: as long as you keep playing there's no way to lose the game. It's more like a movie with a few interactions added here and there. I personally expected a bit of a challenge too but the game was too easy and too linear. But is that necessarily a bad thing?\n\nNo. In my opinion
voteText: it's not.\n\nIn fact
helpfulPercent: because of how straightforward the gameplay is
votesHelpful:
I was able to progress through the story very quickly in anticipation for what's going to happen next. All I had to do was overcome a bit of a hurdle in order to progress through the story and it didn't bother me at all.

That is why I prefer calling it an 'experience' as opposed to calling it a 'game'. It is a  story-driven experience. The lack of any complicated gameplay made all the other aspects of the game shine.

The graphics may be your typical RPG Maker stuff
votesTotal: but it's better-looking than most of the games made through the RPG Maker engine.\n\nThe story...well
votesFunny: without spoiling much let's just say that there are a lot of feels found in this game. One minute I'm laughing at the interactions between the two main characters
commentsCount: and the next minute I'm trying my best to hold back my tears from too much feels (and most of the time failing to hold back said tears; no shame in that).\n\nAnd the music? Oh man
column16: the music...the music in this game is arguably its greatest asset. The music found in the game is very beautiful. Each soundtrack served its purpose in making every scene of the game much more enjoyable and memorable. If you buy the game
column17:
I implore you to buy the soundtrack as well. It's worth it.

It's a short game; only took me around 4 hours to finish. But every second of that 4 hours was worth it. It was a short but sweet ride.

I highly recommend this game."

reviewText: Guaranteed tears; tears of saddness and tears of joy. Tears because you don't want this beautiful game to end. To the moon is incredible if you're into heavily story-based games with minimal gameplay. It's more of a point and click game with the occasional puzzle which gets harder as the game progresses, but it's nothing too mind numbing. What I love about this game is also the comedic relief from the male doctor you play, so it's a good balance of sadness and humour. Whoever wrote the script for this game needs a medal.

reviewText:
The Bad:
-The graphics are pretty terrible.
-There is no real gameplay apart from a few very easy puzzles and your basic explore-and-interact.

The Good:
+The soundtrack is beautiful and used very well throughout the story.
+The story is very well written and extremely emotional. Every detail throughout the game is well planned, every mystery has a great payoff, it all connects brilliantly and the dialogue (Text only, no voice acting) is really good.

Overall, you play as 2 scientists who alter dying people's memories to fulfill a wish for them (or, at least, make them believe it came true). In this case, they're out to help an old man called John H. Wyles, who's dying wish is to go (you guessed it) to the moon. What makes this case a bit different to their normal ones is that Johnny hasn't the faintest idea as to why he even wants that. He just knows he does.

The game's divided into 3 acts. The first one is mostly about establishing the backstory and leanring about Johnny's life. It's pretty slow paced, and mostly sets up questions to be answered later. The 2nd act picks up the pace, and from there till the end I found the game hard to stop playing.

It takes a bit over 3 hours to finish, so I recommend finishing it in 1 sitting for maximum impact.

This game is a wonderful memory.  Everyone should play it.

reviewText: Wow. I played this all in one sitting. Start to finish. Absolutely brilliant. Could not put it down. It's like if someone took Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind and combined it with Inception to a create a story about doctors who dive into the memories of the dying to artificially fulfill their dying wish by creatively revising their memories (emphasis on Eternal Sunshine). I was initially (and perhaps unfairly) skeptical of what a story could do with pixel art, but am happy to say I was quite wrong. This was much, much better than I expected. I appreciated all the subtle but extremely significant connections that go completely unmentioned, providing deep rewards for the more perceptive and analytical story-focused players. The story also does beautiful things with an autism spectrum character that left me very impressed. A++ more please.

reviewText:
在某吧友的建议下，昨天一口气把游戏《去月球》通关了，这款被称作神作（神作泛滥的时代）的作品，感动了那么多人，但是我个人倒是没怎么感冒，还有点不以为然。
虽然是很美丽的爱情故事，虽然我多多少少也为之动容了一点，即使改变了记忆也没有错过爱你的人，爱你的人终究还是爱你，多么美好浪漫的事情，但是因为科幻色彩浓重，加上本来对爱情就失望透顶的我，竟会觉得有点坑，果然是因为初期对游戏的期望太高了吗？当然，还有其他一些原因，后续说明。
据说游戏的容量是4个小时，因为是抽时间出来玩这个游戏的，所以我是抱着快速通关的心理去玩这款游戏的，这个在一定程度上影响了我去好好地欣赏它，不过既然是剧情游戏的话，文字当然是很重要的，我有好好地看游戏中的每一句台词。
初期以为游戏中要打怪兽什么的，我甚至都做好了使用修改器的准备（为了快速通关），但是实际玩了一会儿之后发现不需要打怪，这点让我很喜欢，而是类似于发现道具做任务一样的游戏流程。
游戏充满了科幻要素，剧中的台词也很有意思，两个博士都属于很可爱的人，尤其是男博士，虽然看上去吊儿郎当的，但是实际上是个很实在的人，也可以看得出来很喜欢女博士。
于是，二人组就开始到病人的记忆里去穿梭了，不过我开始就有疑问，如果只是篡改记忆的话，那么实际上不是还是没有达到“让约翰去月球”的愿望了吗？就是说，只是篡改了记忆让那些事“好像是真的”，但是实际上仍然是一场梦不是吗？这让人稍微绝点有点坑，真的去月球的话又是没可能的，一个垂死的病人又是要如何才能够去到月球呢。
游戏的过程中，因为程序bug原因意外卡住一次，害我只能从上一个存档载入也坑了我一把。还因为人物不能奔跑让我很是着急，于是我使用了变速齿轮，将速度×4之后终于可以比较顺利地“奔跑”了。
一个类似倒叙的故事，让我们先知道了结果，然后再去寻找原因，历程还有点坎坷，中间有一次不知道怎么攻略下去了因为找不到记忆要素，本来就想快速通关的我，不能顺利攻略让人有点着急，于是只好看了一下攻略然后总算顺利通关了。
剧情的高潮就是二人对于如何处理病人的委托意见发生了分歧，要说二人都是没错的，最后折中的方案成功了也算是万幸了，在那之前女博士临危不惧也让人动容。
老人了无遗憾地走了，房子给了佣人莉莉，结尾处红色的闪屏仿佛暗示了什么，比如这发生的一切其实只是一次某人的记忆的探索历程。
于是故事就结束了，我没有被感动，但是却有着淡淡的感伤，不知道是这游戏带给我的感伤，还是我最近因为工作上的事情本来就感到压力大了，亦或者是其他。
游戏的体裁还是很喜欢的，科幻类型，冒险要素和游戏手法都是挺不错的，还有音乐也很赞，尤其是主题曲那首音乐《去月球》，再次听到的时候这个故事自然就浮现在脑海里了。
喜欢浪漫爱情故事的朋友或许可以试试这个据说超过《仙剑》的RPG游戏

reviewText: To The Moon is one of those games you instantly fall in love with. With it's simple, but elegant design, incredible writing, and thrilling, heartfelt tale, To The Moon is more story than game. To the Moon's excellent storytelling never veers off course and is one of the best I've experienced.\n\nTo the Moon is a game you must play. It's available for $9.99, which seems about right for this affecting four-hour tale, but I recommend to wait for the game to be on sale.

reviewText: This was probably my favorite game ive played this year. It was brutally beautiful, like watching the first thirty minutes of Up backwards repeatedly - in a good way. Also, do not buy this without the soundtrack, which is equally gorgeous. Graphics and art style were very reminiscent of Chrono Trigger, though the controlls were a little clunky, like some of the other less well designed SNES titles, and the few puzzles were far too easy. But the story, art, and music's amazingness completely eclipsed anything that could be found wrong elsewhere. I was completely blown away. You must play this game, if only to watch your soul shed a few scars, and your heart become a little less cold.

This, along with TellTales The Walking Dead, and a few others that I can't remember at this late hour, all fall into this stable of must-ride stallions (This joke will make sense once you buy the game). reviewText:
The following contains NO spoilers:
A nicely told love story about an old man... a man... a teen... a boy and a girl... a teen... a woman... an old lady. The story follows two scientists that travel backwards through a man's memories while trying to find a way to input a new memory.

I was surprised by the way the developers proved that telling the story backwards was the right way to do it. It's not only a thing of finding out how it all started but also understanding some bits of dialogue that although they didn't seem out of place, you couldn't truly understand at the time (even when you had no idea that they were important)
I finished the game in about three hours and the lenght was spot on, it's well paced and frankly really good.

Ps: I really think this could become a good short anime series (about 5 or 6 episodes long), I know it hardly has to do with the review, but it's just a thought that came to me.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: To the Moon is an amazing story more than a game. You follow a dying man's life memories backwards to implant an artificial memory of him fullfilling his lifelong wish to go to the moon, thereby letting him have a happy memory before he passes. It's not until you reach his childhood memories do you understand the missing pieces and why he wants to go the moon in the first place. It's extremely sentimental, heartfelt, and touching. The soundtrack is so good and beautiful. The game is worth every penny.

reviewText:
Oh meh god, where do I even start. This game... this game, is a needle in a haystack. What a unique game, I'm very foutunate to use my hard earn money to give this game a shot and what I got back was mixed emotions; as I laughed, cried, smiled, frowned, and all other possible humane facial expressions out there. All because of a typical RPG game running for 4-5 hours about John's or Joey's life.

Joey.....

Those types of scenes, I couldn't believe that any one espically an indie gaming company can come up with these occurances that can really hit you in the feels. Knowing that John would die at any moment + Eva and Neil doing their job and making sacrifices to fulfull John's last wish + John's childhood + The soundtrack (espically the piano instrumentals and Laura Shigihara's voice of an angel) + The reoccuring rude remarks of Neil + Eva having to deal with all that.... and +...

River.... She was basically the icing of the cake in this game for her unique character... As she was limited by her autism, she really made her life complete in both reality and in John's visions. Their relationship is what made this game the most relatable, two different backgrounds and personalities; as they ended up living through the moments together through childhood to death and John's decision to change his memories before he leaves his life, really completed the couple.

I cri everitim...

Looking for a sequel as promised, Freebird Games... If not, replay levels are over 9000, speaking of over 9000

+9000/10

reviewText: To the Moon is one of those works whose very nature places it at a disadvantage. Like a kicker on an American Football team, this genre (which is most satisfactorially described as an interactive experience") is not comparable to its peers since it doesn't do the same thing they do. But in all fairness its peers likewise cannot match what it does
date:
and you'd better believe it does plenty!

The Negs --
This title catches you off-guard
recommended: withholding the real meat of the gameplay until about 30 minutes in. And even then
hoursPlayed: that gameplay meat is lean-sliced turkey over a bagel at best. The "interactor" (rather than "player") functions to only move characters from one cutscene to the next. To the Moon could be outright categorized as a point-and-click game if it weren't for the RPG presentation it offers. The story mechanics are sometimes inconsistent
voteText: making the goals unclear
helpfulPercent: which is especially frustrating when all you want to do is get the characters to the next scene of dialogue. This frustration is not extensive though. There were some bugs in places
votesHelpful: and sometimes the ground was just too cluttered with vague textures. Quite literally I continually thought the game was freezing on me simply because my character stopped walking when in reality a small flower
votesTotal: not so different in appearance from another small flower that I walk right over
votesFunny: was just blocking my way. The faults of the gameplay were highly bearable
commentsCount: however
column16:
mainly because the gameplay was a minor part of this experience.

The Pos --
Despite all the underwhelming gameplay aspects
column17: this piece held my attention for 5 hours quite easily. The culprit: the characters. Not the main two doctors - I knew about them. What captivated me were the rest of the cast and their unanswered stories. The writing in this game is keen and well-paced
column18: playing coy about the questions it introduces while not leaving the interactor lost for too long. The dialogue ventures into topics that are realistically gritty and gray. This whole experience works in the first place because the user is immersed enough to accept the story and characters at hand. This immersion is influenced by the detailed artwork
column19: which avoided the half-hearted tiling of textures that RPGs are known for
column20: and by the MIND-BLOWING SOUNDTRACK!!!!! I could not give the ost for this work any more laud than it has already received
column21: but if my two cents count for a thing
column22: the music in this game had me consciously framing each scene to its tone
column23:
particularly when the music changed mid-scene.

The Verd --
To the Moon is definitely one to sit down and just experience one day. It is certainly not the sort of thing that I would do any day to blow off some steam; there is a mood for it. So if you find yourself in the mood to watch The Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind but in a form that requires you to read a little more
column24: then pick up To the Moon (there are actually very similar tones between the two works
column25: and the atmospheres line up pretty well too). As a video game it merits a [7 / 10]
column26: but as its own genre of entertainment it steals [10 / 10]. Touching on troubling topics and tearducts alike
column27: To the Moon earned its place as a title that everyone should play once and discuss for a long time after."

reviewText: This isn't so much a game as it is an interactve story. It's sort of... a point-and-click adventure meets a visual novel - and to be up-front, I'm not a big fan of either. That being said, and I don't want to give anything away, this will keep you engaged and wanting to finish the narrative. I can't say there's much replay value, as it's like a good movie... a la The Sixth Sense, where, once you know what happens, that's it. Even still, if I only ever play it once, it was worth every penny for the 4 hour experience. Obviously, if there's a ridiculously good sale, grab it up. If you have it sitting in your Library from the Humble Bundle, fire it up and prepare your feels.\n\n9/10

reviewText:
To The Moon by Freebird games. This is such a great game. One of my favourites for sure. Don't watch the videos on YouTube, just play it. It might look basic/boring, but play it to the end and you will not be disappointed. I highly recommend playing it if you haven't already. [Overall rating 8.5/10]

Gameplay is pretty average. There isn't much exciting about the gameplay. You click to move, search for objects, click objects, talk to NPCs and that is about it. Don't expect a lot from the gameplay but what it lacks here, it excels in storyline and audio. I believe the gameplay is meant to be quite simple so that more people can experience the story. Even though gameplay is a big deal in video games, this game was amazing still. [Gameplay rating 6/10]

Storyline was something else. Beautiful. When you finish the game and reach the credits, you want to applaud... after you've wiped away the tears of course. If' you're just starting this game, I can't stress how important it is to play this game to the end just for that experience alone. The story alone makes up for the simple gameplay and graphics. [Story rating 10/10]

Graphics are retro style, like something from a SNES time RPG. Don't expect something cutting-edge from the graphics, but they are detailed enough for you to see facial expressions and catch the emotions needed. [Graphics rating 8/10]

Audio is amazing. I find that I'm listening to the full soundtrack regularly. The song, Everythings Alright" by Laura Shigihara still gives me the feels when I hear it. Amazing voice
date: and amazing soundtrack. Audio often helps a great deal with infusing emotions into a story
recommended:
this is definitely the case with To The Moon. [Audio rating 10/10]

Instead of showing gameplay or epic moments in the game. I will leave you with a YouTube link for the full soundtrack. Enjoy.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Snl67XsI6Is

See my other reviews here.

reviewText:
I recommend this game whole-heartedly.  I feel like I should say that before stating that I don't think it's much of a game at all.  There are definitely occasional game elements - puzzles, plants and zombies (oh, I get it now), and I'm very proud of the 97% hit rate I got on whack-a-mole - but To the Moon isn't built around any of that.  To the Moon is simply a story: an intricate, emotionally honest, well-crafted story that is an utter amazement to experience.  The rest of this (non-spoiler) review is entirely about the story.

First off: the construction.  I have one criticism here, and it's that the beginning felt like it stretched a bit too long before diving into the meat of the plot.  Other than that, the story is uniformly excellent.  Characters are relatable and flawed and real, and they are expressed organically through the story - shown rather than told.  The pacing of the plot is excellent, as is the rhythm of the frequent beats of humor against the somber moments.  And the overall arc is deftly woven: nothing happens in the end that isn't earned in the beginning, and it is rather amazing how recurring jokes such as the jar of pickled olives are transformed into something far more meaningful by game's end.

Second: the content.  At its core To the Moon is a story about the faith required to have any sort of relationship with another human being.  This is not a point that is hammered in; instead it is subtly expressed in moments spread throughout the game.  Moments where a character is lonelier with someone he loves than by himself.  Where a debate is held over the notion that caring for another can also be selfishness.  Where two people with an asymmetric understanding of each other (and aren't all understandings between two people fundamentally asymmetric?) struggle forward into the future based on nothing more than. . . faith.

I don't think I can go into any more detail without dipping my toe into spoiler territory, and To the Moon deserves better.  I will say that it feels like the story has changed me, colored my notions of the world in ways I can't quite define.  Any game that does that deserves to be played.

I have developed an (unfortunate) habit of including a fairly inane story at the end of my reviews on Steam.  I'm going to pass that up in favor of - again - simply recommending that you enjoy the story of To the Moon.  Here's an attempt at a topical haiku instead!

-----------------------------------------

The moon is an eye
Always watching from above
Nothing else sees all

------------------------------------------

Yeah, you do better.

reviewText:
I am a fan of old school games, pixel/8bit/16bit graphics, but this game just looks awful... Resolution is somewhere along the lines of 640x480, and when put to fullscreen, looks so pixelated... Other than that, it is nicely drawn, and could've been much better...
Interface is also catastrophic, almost unusable... Controls are awkward (don't even try playing it on controller, although it does work), and irritating...

So, after all that, why do I recommend it...
Because it has a beautiful and touching story... And interesting soundtrack... But story is, just fantastic, and it is a game that should really be played for it...
To bad, it doesn't shine on graphical and UI fronts, because it could've been a masterpiece...

reviewText: To the Moon, what can I say about it? The game is absolutely wonderful! It tells the story of a man on his death bed who wants his last wish granted before departing the world. Enter Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts, two scientists who have been hired to grant this dying man's wish before it's too late. You play as Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts and take a journey through the man's life from end to start in this heartwarming adventure. You'll learn about the love of his life, his friends, his family and his one wish!

reviewText:
A game that has to be experienced, it has more humanity and is more affecting than most movies, music, or literature today - a true diamond amongst rubbish if  you can get past its shortcomings.

The gameplay is very tedious and boring, looking objectively, and it was at times frustrating, but for me it was still worth the thousand clicks and badly programmed movement.

The writing was a little amatuerish, I can't help but feel like it was on purpose though. I don't think the writing and dialogue was supposed to be adult and mature. I pretty much ignored the, at times, childish dialogue and focused on the main part.

I still believe it is worth the tiny investment of time and money. Thumbs up!

reviewText: To the Moon is one of those works whose very nature places it at a disadvantage. Like a kicker on an American Football team, this genre (which is most satisfactorially described as an interactive experience") is not comparable to its peers since it doesn't do the same thing they do. But in all fairness its peers likewise cannot match what it does
date:
and you'd better believe it does plenty!

The Negs --
This title catches you off-guard
recommended: withholding the real meat of the gameplay until about 30 minutes in. And even then
hoursPlayed: that gameplay meat is lean-sliced turkey over a bagel at best. The "interactor" (rather than "player") functions to only move characters from one cutscene to the next. To the Moon could be outright categorized as a point-and-click game if it weren't for the RPG presentation it offers. The story mechanics are sometimes inconsistent
voteText: making the goals unclear
helpfulPercent: which is especially frustrating when all you want to do is get the characters to the next scene of dialogue. This frustration is not extensive though. There were some bugs in places
votesHelpful: and sometimes the ground was just too cluttered with vague textures. Quite literally I continually thought the game was freezing on me simply because my character stopped walking when in reality a small flower
votesTotal: not so different in appearance from another small flower that I walk right over
votesFunny: was just blocking my way. The faults of the gameplay were highly bearable
commentsCount: however
column16:
mainly because the gameplay was a minor part of this experience.

The Pos --
Despite all the underwhelming gameplay aspects
column17: this piece held my attention for 5 hours quite easily. The culprit: the characters. Not the main two doctors - I knew about them. What captivated me were the rest of the cast and their unanswered stories. The writing in this game is keen and well-paced
column18: playing coy about the questions it introduces while not leaving the interactor lost for too long. The dialogue ventures into topics that are realistically gritty and gray. This whole experience works in the first place because the user is immersed enough to accept the story and characters at hand. This immersion is influenced by the detailed artwork
column19: which avoided the half-hearted tiling of textures that RPGs are known for
column20: and by the MIND-BLOWING SOUNDTRACK!!!!! I could not give the ost for this work any more laud than it has already received
column21: but if my two cents count for a thing
column22: the music in this game had me consciously framing each scene to its tone
column23:
particularly when the music changed mid-scene.

The Verd --
To the Moon is definitely one to sit down and just experience one day. It is certainly not the sort of thing that I would do any day to blow off some steam; there is a mood for it. So if you find yourself in the mood to watch The Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind but in a form that requires you to read a little more

reviewText: This isn't so much a game as it is an interactve story. It's sort of... a point-and-click adventure meets a visual novel - and to be up-front, I'm not a big fan of either. That being said, and I don't want to give anything away, this will keep you engaged and wanting to finish the narrative. I can't say there's much replay value, as it's like a good movie... a la The Sixth Sense, where, once you know what happens, that's it. Even still, if I only ever play it once, it was worth every penny for the 4 hour experience. Obviously, if there's a ridiculously good sale, grab it up. If you have it sitting in your Library from the Humble Bundle, fire it up and prepare your feels.\n\n9/10

reviewText:
I recommend this game whole-heartedly.  I feel like I should say that before stating that I don't think it's much of a game at all.  There are definitely occasional game elements - puzzles, plants and zombies (oh, I get it now), and I'm very proud of the 97% hit rate I got on whack-a-mole - but To the Moon isn't built around any of that.  To the Moon is simply a story: an intricate, emotionally honest, well-crafted story that is an utter amazement to experience.  The rest of this (non-spoiler) review is entirely about the story.

First off: the construction.  I have one criticism here, and it's that the beginning felt like it stretched a bit too long before diving into the meat of the plot.  Other than that, the story is uniformly excellent.  Characters are relatable and flawed and real, and they are expressed organically through the story - shown rather than told.  The pacing of the plot is excellent, as is the rhythm of the frequent beats of humor against the somber moments.  And the overall arc is deftly woven: nothing happens in the end that isn't earned in the beginning, and it is rather amazing how recurring jokes such as the jar of pickled olives are transformed into something far more meaningful by game's end.

Second: the content.  At its core To the Moon is a story about the faith required to have any sort of relationship with another human being.  This is not a point that is hammered in; instead it is subtly expressed in moments spread throughout the game.  Moments where a character is lonelier with someone he loves than by himself.  Where a debate is held over the notion that caring for another can also be selfishness.  Where two people with an asymmetric understanding of each other (and aren't all understandings between two people fundamentally asymmetric?) struggle forward into the future based on nothing more than. . . faith.

I don't think I can go into any more detail without dipping my toe into spoiler territory, and To the Moon deserves better.  I will say that it feels like the story has changed me, colored my notions of the world in ways I can't quite define.  Any game that does that deserves to be played.

I have developed an (unfortunate) habit of including a fairly inane story at the end of my reviews on Steam.  I'm going to pass that up in favor of - again - simply recommending that you enjoy the story of To the Moon.  Here's an attempt at a topical haiku instead!

-----------------------------------------

The moon is an eye
Always watching from above
Nothing else sees all

------------------------------------------

Yeah, you do better.

reviewText:
I am a fan of old school games, pixel/8bit/16bit graphics, but this game just looks awful... Resolution is somewhere along the lines of 640x480, and when put to fullscreen, looks so pixelated... Other than that, it is nicely drawn, and could've been much better...
Interface is also catastrophic, almost unusable... Controls are awkward (don't even try playing it on controller, although it does work), and irritating...

So, after all that, why do I recommend it...
Because it has a beautiful and touching story... And interesting soundtrack... But story is, just fantastic, and it is a game that should really be played for it...
To bad, it doesn't shine on graphical and UI fronts, because it could've been a masterpiece...

reviewText: Fly Me To The Moon.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
To the Moon is an adventure/story that slowly reveals the life an old man on his death bed and the circumstances surrounding his final wish. Your progression leads you to regress through his memories, piecing together the importance of his request and why he chose it. Clever and heart-wrenching, To the Moon promises a bittersweet storyline and a simple, yet beautiful score to accompany it. The game will make you laugh; it will make you cry; it will make you hope for the fulfillment of your dreams.

Story: 10/10
It's bittersweet and emotionally-engaging. The dialogue between the characters are often funny and clever, drawing from many modern tropes.

Gameplay: 7/10
It features the same type of basic puzzle (with increasing difficulty), intended to give the player some reprieve from just pointing and clicking, and acts as a gate to the next part of the game. Not much variety, but it's what you would expect of a game in its genre.

Controls: 7/10
Point-and-click and if you are so inclined, the arrow keys. Movement is a bit clunky, but not terrible.

Replayability: 5/10
There are no achievements outside of the completion of the game, so unless you want to relive the story again, I don't see why you would replay it.

Fun: 8/10
If your idea of fun is a relaxing game and story time, then this is fun. Think of it as reading an interactive visual novel. That's fun, right?

Conclusion:
If getting hit in the feels is your thing, get this game. If the game is on sale, DEFINITELY get this game. Rarely will you come across story that will incorporate so many of your emotions over the span of only a few hours. It's definitely worth the purchase; the music alone is worth the price of the game.

reviewText:
It's a short but an amazing story driven experience. Only a handful of things were predictable, but not the most important things. The way everything seemed to connect was excellent and I cannot go into too much detail without giving spoilers, so I wont. I will say that the story is quite the tear jerker to some sensitive people, my masculinity barely protected me from drowning my eye sockets.... barely.

Pros
Soundtrack is great, graphics are good for what it was trying to do, story is excellent.
Game has a lot of good funny moments to make up for the depressing moments.
This game is one of few evidences that video games can be art.

Cons
As any story driven game, replay value is nearly non existent. This will be something you will not play again most likely.
Gameplay is non existent. It is like a topdown rpg meets point and click. You are just playing an interactive movie (not necessarly a bad thing imo)
It's pretty short, but considering I wasn't going to stop playing until I finished it the moment I launched it the first time, maybe that was a good thing for me because I gotta go to bed.

reviewText: When I saw that To The Moon looked like something akin to a game made in RPG Maker, I can't say I had particularly high expectations. reviewText:
Simply Amazing!
TL;DR? Get this game! You will not regret its purchase especially at its price. For the five hours you will invest in the game, it will leave a mark on you forever!

Pros:
★ The story is one of the best I've ever experienced.
★ Has a seamless feel to the game keeping you engaged.
★ Cheap but definitely not nasty.
★ The soundtrack is amazing and adds to the story.
★ Left me crying like a little ♥♥♥♥♥.

Cons:
✖ Lack of any real 'gaming' may discourage some.
✖ Left me crying like a little ♥♥♥♥♥.

'To the Moon' would appear to start off like any other indie video game and may take a good five or ten minutes to understand on how it has been set out. But once you fall into the world of mystery that surrounds this game, you quickly become involved in a story that will leave an impressionable memory and have you wanting to reach for the story once again.

Now if you are after action or involvement with a whole heap of WASD key bashing then this game does not suit that purpose. But if you are after a quiet evening and are ready to be involved in an amazing story then 'To the Moon' will be exactly what you are after.

The only hiccup I have with this game is the puzzle sequence and found that it is Freebird's way of calling this a game. Whilst I do enjoy walking around talking to people and exploring the environment I found that the puzzle part wasn't exactly needed in the end development.

Personally I love the piano and this game hits all of the perfect tones for the emotions it's trying to set. The music to this game plays a big part to each area you walk into and sets the mood very nicely. I don't want to give too much away as the mystery of the game is the gem in itself, but I promise you will find a connection to every single character that you find in the game.

This is a game I know I will come back to in years time to come, just so I can listen to its story once again like any great book.

reviewText:
This game has been in my library for quite some time, only when a friend recommended this that I started playing it one bored afternoon. I'm quite open to games but nonetheless I honestly thought this game was going to be boring after browsing through the store page. But seeing that it was recommended to me and that it's also got great reviews, I decided to start it. I didn't know what to expect, the game starts off a bit confusing as it's premise was very new to me, and I'm sure it  will be as well for some of you. What caught my attention and....emotions was the characters, their decisions, motivations and story. It all got me curious and I continued on wanting to learn more as I also got attached to them, some scenes are very heartwarming and sweet and others are innocent and depressing. The way the story is laid out in terms of memory links creates a very interesting and strong medium that makes it very easy to relate and observe the characters from.

The game was never frustrating and you'll definitely find yourself pausing occasionally, if you're like me that enjoys a good soundtrack whilst revering the scenes and characters.

This is certaintly a great game, if you are looking for a great story, short game with a great soundtrack, I'll also highly recommend this to you.

reviewText: One of my favourite stories told in any medium, and a brilliant bit of science fiction.\nUnlike 99.9% of games, I feel like the creator really had something he wanted to say, and unfortunately for him he wasn't involved with a big animation studio that could have turned this into a wonderful film. Instead, he made a game out of it, one with lacklustre gameplay and interactive elements that don't add anything to (and can sometimes halt) the wonderful narrative.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
To the Moon is not really a game, but more like... interactive fiction. The two Docs are helping this old man who said he wanted to go to the moon, but he can't remember why. By going back in his memory and hopefully by stitching it back together in a certain way, they can reweave the memory to allow the mind to fill in the details, thus allowing the patient to die with a sense of fulfillment rather than regret. Except the Doctors have met their match... as there are some secrets that this man is hiding... and they must search through the catacombs of his memories to locate the clues...

Don't let the cute 2D graphics that resemble Japanese console RPG turn you off. This game is MUCH deeper than that. They simply chose to spend the developement time on the story rather than hiring artists to do bazillion illustrations. At its heart, its a love story, about broken promises, unfilfilled wishes and potentials, and about taking chances, and how one encounter can change a life.

It is a short game, and you should have no problem finishing it in a few hours. And you may be shedding a few tears at the end.

reviewText:
I played To The Moon after some heavy insistence of a friend of mine. At the first sights I felt attracted to its detailed scenarios although the cartoonish style of the characters were something of a drawback. However, the more I got into the story, and felt puzzled by it, the more that world seemed believable and the more its characters grew on my mind.

Have you read a compelling book and felt the desperate urge to turn pages and pages because you HAD to know what was going to happen?  Playing To The Moon is like reading one of those books, there is a point in the story where you CAN'T turn back and you have to fulfill the quest.

This is a game of mild exploration, mild puzzles and increasingly beauty in its storyline. I felt compelled to finish it just like first the time I play Max Payne, and although the story has nothing to do with revenge and bloody murder, the kind of urgency, of NEED to see what will happens, is the very same.

Also, the game has some funny moments where you can't help but laughing hard (I did it and it was 2 A.M.!). Last but not least, To The Moon is graced with an a awesome soundtrack, it might be a bit repetitive, but all the songs fit perfectly in the right moments, not just being a background noise, but their piece of the stroy with their beauty.

If you like playing games for their stories, then this is for you!

reviewText:
My Review :

Rate  : 11/10 would board the Feel Train again!

Game Information :
Modes : Single Player
Genre : Indie, Clicker Game, RPG
Engine : RPG Maker
Developer : Freebird Games
Platforms : Windows, Mac & Linux
Release Date : 1 Nov, 2011
ROW Lowest Price : 1.49$ at Steam

Might contain some spoilers!

To The Moon is an Indie RPG created by Freebird Games. The game follows Dr. Neil Watts and Dr. Eva Rosalene, employees of Sigmund Corporation, whose job it is to fulfill the final wishes of elderly people who are about to die.They do this by using a machine that allows them to go back through their patient's memories and influence them to fulfill their wishes, creating the memories of their wishes being fulfilled for the patient. In the game, the patient is an elderly man named Johnny, whose dream is to go to the moon. However, he does not know why he wants to go to the moon, so the doctors must find out why he wants to go in order to influence him to go. The doctors go through his memories, from being an elderly man to being a child, in a race against time to get him to the moon before he passes away. The game also delves into the lives of people in Johnny's life, such as his wife River, his friend Nicholas, Isabelle and others.
Though this game has rich story and great soundtrack, it is still click to proceed type game. Its still worth playing and enjoying.

Free DLCs :
● Sigmund Minisode 1

● Sigmund Minisode 2

Final Review :
Why are you still reading my review, buy and play this amazing game now.

reviewText: Wow, there are just no other words to describe this game. It is primarily a point and click adventure, with simple puzzles and simple navigation, the gameplay never was meant to be the focus. What you're getting is an emotional rollercoaster that will have you laughing, crying, cheering, tension...ing... and you will love every second of it, well... unless you're incapable of feeling emotions, in which case this probably isn't for you. Also, if you're afraid of others seeing you as not being the manliest of men, this probably isn't for you. Also, you may like to have a box of tissues sitting next to you because you'll become snotty and face watery and it won't be pretty, but you'll love every second of it. The soundtrack is also the most amazing piece I have heard which adds a lot to the experience!\n\nOne of the sappiest, cheesiest games I've played ever, get it noooow!!!

reviewText:
Powerful story. Quick game but really touches you. I was very impressed how small the development team was and how much they were able to accomplish. I cannot really tell you much about the game since the story should be experienced as a whole without any hints, but I can say that it is the journey of a man's life and how two scientists figure out why he wants to go to the moon, hence the title.

This game probably could be beaten in one sitting, 3~4 hours.

It gets you very emotionally invested in the characters, and the plot is very thick and rich with cool details and sequence of events of things that will tie in later that eventually come back to support an idea of the story. The use of the flashback and the overall mood and tone the game creates is unique and special.

9.5/10, very worthwhile. Definitely buying the sequel when it comes out.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I stopped playing Mass Effect 3 for almost three months before I could finish it when I lost one of my favorite characters towards the end due to my own shortcomings. I leveled Cloud and friends for hours on end to try and keep her from dying (name held for spoiler protection) in FFVII. I replayed the same misison in Wing Commander II over and over to try and save Spirit. However sad I felt, it always was a game to me and never shed a tear. Not even close.

Played To the Moon, and cried enough to rival that of my lifetime. Many may have missed the many many nuances of the story, and after completion I suggest reading up on it. This story takes reality by the feet and drags into the realm of Science Fiction. Every element, color choice, and dialogue is carefully placed to further the central focus of this game, the story. This emotional story/journey is the central focus (not gameplay, graphics, or gimmics) and is something so memorable. For me, I felt the tear jerking moment coming... but still caught me completely off guard. Excellent sound track. Bravo. Well done.

Will play again when I actually man up and buy tissues.
10/10

reviewText: As an individual with Asperger's syndrome, I found this to be a very touching story that made it very difficult to retain my bodily fluids. Where this game lacks in gameplay (There is hardly any) it makes up with its deep plot line, pleasent soundtrack, and references to pop culture.\nIf you were to choose to purchase this title, I would recommend getting some bags of chips (or just pick your nose the entire time, I don't care) and taking in the entire game in a single sitting.\nI shall not give this a number rating because everybody will understand and percieve it differently, but for anybody who can appreciate a work of art that tells a touching tale, I would reccomend this from the bottom of my heart.

reviewText: This game... I don't even know what to say. It made me cry... multiple times. reviewText:
I am a fan of old school games, pixel/8bit/16bit graphics, but this game just looks awful... Resolution is somewhere along the lines of 640x480, and when put to fullscreen, looks so pixelated... Other than that, it is nicely drawn, and could've been much better...
Interface is also catastrophic, almost unusable... Controls are awkward (don't even try playing it on controller, although it does work), and irritating...

So, after all that, why do I recommend it...
Because it has a beautiful and touching story... And interesting soundtrack... But story is, just fantastic, and it is a game that should really be played for it...
To bad, it doesn't shine on graphical and UI fronts, because it could've been a masterpiece...

reviewText:
A game that has to be experienced, it has more humanity and is more affecting than most movies, music, or literature today - a true diamond amongst rubbish if  you can get past its shortcomings.

The gameplay is very tedious and boring, looking objectively, and it was at times frustrating, but for me it was still worth the thousand clicks and badly programmed movement.

The writing was a little amatuerish, I can't help but feel like it was on purpose though. I don't think the writing and dialogue was supposed to be adult and mature. I pretty much ignored the, at times, childish dialogue and focused on the main part.

I still believe it is worth the tiny investment of time and money. Thumbs up!

reviewText:
To the Moon (tl;dr review)

Graphics: 16-bit art style with some beautiful sprites, tiles, etc.

Sound: Amazing Soundtrack.

Gameplay: More of a pixel visual novel" than a game. But there are some puzzles to solve (even you can solve it
date:
trust me)

Story/Lore/Quests: Story made me cry. Great Drama with cleverly incorporated comic relief.

tl;dr
Carefully crafted piece of interactive storytelling with a moving plot and well elaborated characters supported and enhanced by a stunning soundtrack. If you can ignore the fact (or just don't care) that the gameplay is rather flat or happen to acknowlegde that "To the Moon" isn't really a game (in fact I don't think that it even tries to be a game) but a unique story waiting to be read (kind of like a western retro visual novel)
recommended: you will experience something that will be worth your time (and money
hoursPlayed:
trust me).

tl;dr of the tl;dr
WORTH THE MONEY. GET IT ASAP."
