reviewText:
A Paladin’s Steam Review: To The Moon. A Lot of Feels Story, not a Lot of Gameplay.Genre: Sci-Fi Adventure Comedy/Tragedy Story Driven Experience.
Developed & Published by: Freebird Games
Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux.
Business Model: Base Game
Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Story Thoughts & Gameplay Mechanics
The story is about two doctors who provide a service to people on their deathbeds. This service they perform is where they go into the person’s memories and change events in their head so that it concludes how they would prefer. The game is focused on one such patient and uncovering pieces of his past. There’s some interesting subjects brought up in the game, about life and death. About the moral and philosophical questions brought up about what these two are doing and the actions with regards to the patient. That being said, I feel like this is a game best experienced by yourself. It's not a story I really want to get into or dissect, as I feel that takes away from the experience. I won't deny that this is a bit of a cop-out but at the same time, that's why I don't usually cover titles like To the Moon all that often. I find them difficult to cover.

The gameplay amounts to you finding certain important items on the level and advancing the story along. There’s not a lot that you, the player, can do when it comes to this game. A lot of the game expects to be watched and read, so there’s not much variance to the experience worth nothing. I get that narrative-driven games are like this, but, it’s getting more and more tiresome.

PC Settings
Settings for this game are extremely lacking. No resolution options (it runs in a 640x480 resolution), v-sync option is hidden away in the game properties menu which is only accessible by pressing F1 in-game (not something that’s made immediately clear I might add). Keybindings can be changed for both controller and mouse + keyboard though. There are separate volume sliders as well.

The graphics are a 2D pixelated affair, with a top-down jRPG-like camera angle. Music is an instrumental affair with a lot of solo piano and strings. It works well to create a morose sort of weight to the game.

Side note: the free DLC story that comes with To the Moon doesn't play on anything but Windows. It's ok, a nice little freebie.

Final Thoughts
To the Moon is pretty good. The story certainly has its feels and the game is laser focused on telling a tight story. I’ll give them credit that despite being a passive observer for the majority of it, they clearly knew what they wanted to tell. It’s not an entirely passive affair but the most you’ll end up doing is finding items to advance the plot along, moving around rooms and talking with people. There’s some interesting philosophical and ethical questions about death that are brought up as well. Other than that, what’s left to say...

Read the review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

reviewText:
It's a short but an amazing story driven experience. Only a handful of things were predictable, but not the most important things. The way everything seemed to connect was excellent and I cannot go into too much detail without giving spoilers, so I wont. I will say that the story is quite the tear jerker to some sensitive people, my masculinity barely protected me from drowning my eye sockets.... barely.

Pros
Soundtrack is great, graphics are good for what it was trying to do, story is excellent.
Game has a lot of good funny moments to make up for the depressing moments.
This game is one of few evidences that video games can be art.

Cons
As any story driven game, replay value is nearly non existent. This will be something you will not play again most likely.
Gameplay is non existent. It is like a topdown rpg meets point and click. You are just playing an interactive movie (not necessarly a bad thing imo)
It's pretty short, but considering I wasn't going to stop playing until I finished it the moment I launched it the first time, maybe that was a good thing for me because I gotta go to bed.

reviewText:
I can't even begin to describe how brilliant this game is. I didn't really know what to expect going in, except that the game had gotten really good reviews, and that it was about going through a guy's memories. Turns out it's one of the best games I've ever played, and probably one of the most well-conceived and well-written indie games ever made. The way everything ties together as you work your way backwards through the memories is put together pretty much flawlessly. I couldn't find any discontinuity anywhere.

The feels hit me harder than any form of media has since the show Chuck, and it's also genuinely hilarious at all the right moments. One of the characters in particular made me laugh out loud at his clever references and dialogue in pretty much every scene. I love how it's not so over-the-top funny that it comes off as trying too hard. It's just the perfect amount of humour.

One piece of advice, I would recommend setting aside a good 5-6 hours and just playing the game straight through. The characters you play as are pulling an all-nighter"
date: and I feel that the game is best experienced in the same way - all at once. I took a break for a couple weeks part-way through
hoursPlayed: it took me a little while to remember what had happened.\n\nTL;DR: BUY. ABSOLUTELY WORTH $11."

reviewText: 9.5/10\nI've always thought indie games were just the cheap way of making a game and after this game, I lost that view entirely. I bought this because it was on sale and I wanted to try something new and short. I did not expect this game to be as great as it was and only started it out of boredom. I'm so glad I did. **The reason my hours are shorter than most is because it was played on offline mode most of the time**\nThe story is unique with many plot twists. The company doesn't put too much work into gameplay because it's the story you are supposed to focus on. If you expect it to be a full shooting and destroy everything game, you'll get a few puzzles for your enjoyment. You play as Johnny and has a very quiet wife, and although she doesn't say much she is one of the most loving characters in the game. The graphics are also quite nice in an indie way. You CANNOT play this game in long breaks, it's one you'd want to continue and even if you didn't, the ending is cute so go play to the end anyways. I've recommended this game to three people so far, and all three love and enjoyed it as much as I did. It's simplistic gameplay with a strong story makes one amazing game.

reviewText: This game is beautiful. Having just completed the game, I can only say this. You may laugh, you may cry. Feelings will move, and your heart will feel it. It is advertised as an emotionally provocative adventure, and it delivers. I completed the game in 5 hours (taking into consideration that at some points I may have had to pause to do other things) and I wish I had done it all in one sitting. reviewText: To The Moon is a perfect mix of Memento and Inception. The game tells one of the best narratives in any game and although the gameplay is incredibly sparse, it manages to more than compensate with a story that has great depth. The game goes through the memories of the character John in mainly reverse chronological order, similarly to Memento, and as such it reveals more of the true story as the background is revealed and the subsequent events become more clear and meaningful. The soundtrack greatly adds to the experience as well, pulling you into the scene and helping create a greater emotional impact. Overall, it is definitely worth a buy and at around 3 hours for a playtrough, anyone can definitely finish.

reviewText: An amazing game. It's not you're typical game, and it will make you question some things about life: like most empathy games. At the end, I had a tear in my eye. That's all you really need to know. Yes, it looks like bog-standard RPG maker output, but  play it for a little while and you'll be living through each moment with the characters and aching to find out where it's going next.

reviewText:
Powerful story. Quick game but really touches you. I was very impressed how small the development team was and how much they were able to accomplish. I cannot really tell you much about the game since the story should be experienced as a whole without any hints, but I can say that it is the journey of a man's life and how two scientists figure out why he wants to go to the moon, hence the title.

This game probably could be beaten in one sitting, 3~4 hours.

It gets you very emotionally invested in the characters, and the plot is very thick and rich with cool details and sequence of events of things that will tie in later that eventually come back to support an idea of the story. The use of the flashback and the overall mood and tone the game creates is unique and special.

9.5/10, very worthwhile. Definitely buying the sequel when it comes out.

reviewText:
This game was truely a great experience, and I very much enjoyed playing it. So I would definietly recommend you to buy it, even for its full price, because this is the kind of developer we should be supporting.

The game was a pleasent surprise, as it offered much more than what I had expected from a 2D RPG. The story caught my attention right from the very beginning and it never really went dull. The characters were interesting, and I found the music to be very nice and suiting to the rest of the game. The game mechanics wasn't anything out of the ordinary, and honestly it didn't really need to be either.

I found the game to be very well polished, and of very high quality, and I would definietly say its one of the best 2D RPG games that I have ever played on PC.

Pros:
+ Great storyline, with a very nice paced progression.
+ The length of the game is just perfect, and it never feels too slow or too fast.
+ Well developed characters.
+ Great sense of humor, without being too over the top.
+ Nice and suiting music.
+ Easy to get 100% steam achievement ( if you care about that )

Cons:
- I can't really think of anything bad to say.

reviewText: This was probably my favorite game ive played this year. It was brutally beautiful, like watching the first thirty minutes of Up backwards repeatedly - in a good way. Also, do not buy this without the soundtrack, which is equally gorgeous. Graphics and art style were very reminiscent of Chrono Trigger, though the controlls were a little clunky, like some of the other less well designed SNES titles, and the few puzzles were far too easy. But the story, art, and music's amazingness completely eclipsed anything that could be found wrong elsewhere. I was completely blown away. You must play this game, if only to watch your soul shed a few scars, and your heart become a little less cold.

reviewText: A beautiful story about trying to fulfill a dying man's mysterious wish. One of the best written games in a long time, with bits of comedy and some heart wrenching reveals throughout the story that deals with a few heavy topics without being blunt about it. There is some gameplay to be had, but it's very shallow and not the real purpose in the first place. Probably the first romantic game I've ever seen outside the visual novel genre, they were are similiarities to be had.

reviewText:
This game has been in my library for quite some time, only when a friend recommended this that I started playing it one bored afternoon. I'm quite open to games but nonetheless I honestly thought this game was going to be boring after browsing through the store page. But seeing that it was recommended to me and that it's also got great reviews, I decided to start it. I didn't know what to expect, the game starts off a bit confusing as it's premise was very new to me, and I'm sure it  will be as well for some of you. What caught my attention and....emotions was the characters, their decisions, motivations and story. It all got me curious and I continued on wanting to learn more as I also got attached to them, some scenes are very heartwarming and sweet and others are innocent and depressing. The way the story is laid out in terms of memory links creates a very interesting and strong medium that makes it very easy to relate and observe the characters from.

The game was never frustrating and you'll definitely find yourself pausing occasionally, if you're like me that enjoys a good soundtrack whilst revering the scenes and characters.

This is certaintly a great game, if you are looking for a great story, short game with a great soundtrack, I'll also highly recommend this to you.

reviewText:
Simply Amazing!
TL;DR? Get this game! You will not regret its purchase especially at its price. For the five hours you will invest in the game, it will leave a mark on you forever!

Pros:
★ The story is one of the best I've ever experienced.
★ Has a seamless feel to the game keeping you engaged.
★ Cheap but definitely not nasty.
★ The soundtrack is amazing and adds to the story.
★ Left me crying like a little ♥♥♥♥♥.

Cons:
✖ Lack of any real 'gaming' may discourage some.
✖ Left me crying like a little ♥♥♥♥♥.

'To the Moon' would appear to start off like any other indie video game and may take a good five or ten minutes to understand on how it has been set out. But once you fall into the world of mystery that surrounds this game, you quickly become involved in a story that will leave an impressionable memory and have you wanting to reach for the story once again.

Now if you are after action or involvement with a whole heap of WASD key bashing then this game does not suit that purpose. But if you are after a quiet evening and are ready to be involved in an amazing story then 'To the Moon' will be exactly what you are after.

The only hiccup I have with this game is the puzzle sequence and found that it is Freebird's way of calling this a game. Whilst I do enjoy walking around talking to people and exploring the environment I found that the puzzle part wasn't exactly needed in the end development.

Personally I love the piano and this game hits all of the perfect tones for the emotions it's trying to set. The music to this game plays a big part to each area you walk into and sets the mood very nicely. I don't want to give too much away as the mystery of the game is the gem in itself, but I promise you will find a connection to every single character that you find in the game.

This is a game I know I will come back to in years time to come, just so I can listen to its story once again like any great book.

reviewText:
To the Moon is not really a game, but more like... interactive fiction. The two Docs are helping this old man who said he wanted to go to the moon, but he can't remember why. By going back in his memory and hopefully by stitching it back together in a certain way, they can reweave the memory to allow the mind to fill in the details, thus allowing the patient to die with a sense of fulfillment rather than regret. Except the Doctors have met their match... as there are some secrets that this man is hiding... and they must search through the catacombs of his memories to locate the clues...

Don't let the cute 2D graphics that resemble Japanese console RPG turn you off. This game is MUCH deeper than that. They simply chose to spend the developement time on the story rather than hiring artists to do bazillion illustrations. At its heart, its a love story, about broken promises, unfilfilled wishes and potentials, and about taking chances, and how one encounter can change a life.

It is a short game, and you should have no problem finishing it in a few hours. And you may be shedding a few tears at the end.

reviewText:
A Paladin’s Steam Review: To The Moon. A Lot of Feels Story, not a Lot of Gameplay.Genre: Sci-Fi Adventure Comedy/Tragedy Story Driven Experience.
Developed & Published by: Freebird Games
Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux.
Business Model: Base Game
Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Story Thoughts & Gameplay Mechanics
The story is about two doctors who provide a service to people on their deathbeds. This service they perform is where they go into the person’s memories and change events in their head so that it concludes how they would prefer. The game is focused on one such patient and uncovering pieces of his past. There’s some interesting subjects brought up in the game, about life and death. About the moral and philosophical questions brought up about what these two are doing and the actions with regards to the patient. That being said, I feel like this is a game best experienced by yourself. It's not a story I really want to get into or dissect, as I feel that takes away from the experience. I won't deny that this is a bit of a cop-out but at the same time, that's why I don't usually cover titles like To the Moon all that often. I find them difficult to cover.

The gameplay amounts to you finding certain important items on the level and advancing the story along. There’s not a lot that you, the player, can do when it comes to this game. A lot of the game expects to be watched and read, so there’s not much variance to the experience worth nothing. I get that narrative-driven games are like this, but, it’s getting more and more tiresome.

PC Settings
Settings for this game are extremely lacking. No resolution options (it runs in a 640x480 resolution), v-sync option is hidden away in the game properties menu which is only accessible by pressing F1 in-game (not something that’s made immediately clear I might add). Keybindings can be changed for both controller and mouse + keyboard though. There are separate volume sliders as well.

The graphics are a 2D pixelated affair, with a top-down jRPG-like camera angle. Music is an instrumental affair with a lot of solo piano and strings. It works well to create a morose sort of weight to the game.

Side note: the free DLC story that comes with To the Moon doesn't play on anything but Windows. It's ok, a nice little freebie.

Final Thoughts
To the Moon is pretty good. The story certainly has its feels and the game is laser focused on telling a tight story. I’ll give them credit that despite being a passive observer for the majority of it, they clearly knew what they wanted to tell. It’s not an entirely passive affair but the most you’ll end up doing is finding items to advance the plot along, moving around rooms and talking with people. There’s some interesting philosophical and ethical questions about death that are brought up as well. Other than that, what’s left to say...

reviewText:
A Paladin’s Steam Review: To The Moon. A Lot of Feels Story, not a Lot of Gameplay.Genre: Sci-Fi Adventure Comedy/Tragedy Story Driven Experience.
Developed & Published by: Freebird Games
Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux.
Business Model: Base Game
Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Story Thoughts & Gameplay Mechanics
The story is about two doctors who provide a service to people on their deathbeds. This service they perform is where they go into the person’s memories and change events in their head so that it concludes how they would prefer. The game is focused on one such patient and uncovering pieces of his past. There’s some interesting subjects brought up in the game, about life and death. About the moral and philosophical questions brought up about what these two are doing and the actions with regards to the patient. That being said, I feel like this is a game best experienced by yourself. It's not a story I really want to get into or dissect, as I feel that takes away from the experience. I won't deny that this is a bit of a cop-out but at the same time, that's why I don't usually cover titles like To the Moon all that often. I find them difficult to cover.

The gameplay amounts to you finding certain important items on the level and advancing the story along. There’s not a lot that you, the player, can do when it comes to this game. A lot of the game expects to be watched and read, so there’s not much variance to the experience worth nothing. I get that narrative-driven games are like this, but, it’s getting more and more tiresome.

PC Settings
Settings for this game are extremely lacking. No resolution options (it runs in a 640x480 resolution), v-sync option is hidden away in the game properties menu which is only accessible by pressing F1 in-game (not something that’s made immediately clear I might add). Keybindings can be changed for both controller and mouse + keyboard though. There are separate volume sliders as well.

The graphics are a 2D pixelated affair, with a top-down jRPG-like camera angle. Music is an instrumental affair with a lot of solo piano and strings. It works well to create a morose sort of weight to the game.

Side note: the free DLC story that comes with To the Moon doesn't play on anything but Windows. It's ok, a nice little freebie.

Final Thoughts
To the Moon is pretty good. The story certainly has its feels and the game is laser focused on telling a tight story. I’ll give them credit that despite being a passive observer for the majority of it, they clearly knew what they wanted to tell. It’s not an entirely passive affair but the most you’ll end up doing is finding items to advance the plot along, moving around rooms and talking with people. There’s some interesting philosophical and ethical questions about death that are brought up as well. Other than that, what’s left to say...

date: To the Moon more than makes up for it in its intriguing and heartfelt narrative. It intertwines humor and heartfelt drama under a veil of mystery--keeping the player hooked from start to finish. I'm amazed at what this game achieves. If you're looking for in-depth gameplay and top-notch graphics then this probably isn't what you're looking for. However

reviewText:
Simply wonderful.
No words can describe how beautiful the story was; it's the best story I have ever read in my life. The soundtrack was what captured the mood of the story, and the story was what captured my amazement.

John is your client, and before he dies he has one final wish, which is to go to the moon. You have to traverse his memory in order to convince his younger self to make certain decisions. As you progress, the picture of the puzzle will start to come into place, and that's when you realise things were not that simple. The plot-twists were what kept this story intriguing, and will leave you in your seat to find out the why of things.

Every cloud has a silver lining. If you had a chance to relive your life, would you change anything?

10/10 - Outstanding story & soundtrack

reviewText:
This game has such a phoneomenal story. The gameplay is fairly linear and simple but it acts as the perfect vehicle for something like this. It definitely could go a lot further with some of its elements but that may be what they intend to do with the sequel that is in the works.

When I played this I literally could not stop until it was all over. It was so emotionally charged and engaging that I stayed up all night to finish it and I really love sleep. There were so many moments in this game that made me cry (in both the sad and the extremely happy ways).

It has the feel of many SNES RPGs so if you played a number of those growing up it will manage to pull at those nostalgic heart strings as well.

Play this game. It's cheap and doesn't take long to complete. It's such an amazing experience that I could not imagine I would willingly pass it up.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Great story with terrible graphics (game runs on a stupidly small resolution with no options to change that). The gameplay mostly consists of walking around, clicking on things and reading the dialogue. But the writing is excellent. The story is about a dying man whose last wish is to go to the moon. You play as the employees of a corporation that is capable of altering people's memories to give them the illusion of having a different life thus fulfilling their last wish before they die. The narrative unfolds in a reverse chronological order as you go back in time through the old man's memories, learning about his life and finding a way to make his wish come true. It's an interesting way to tell a story and it's executed quite well here.

reviewText:
To The Moon...
It was short; it only took me around 4 hours to complete. Despite being an RPGMaker game, there's no combat anywhere; it's almost entirely story driven, with a handful of puzzles here and there. Said puzzles were simple, yet rather entertaining. The story is very unsual, though not entirely unique; these sorts of ideas appear from time to time.
But above everything else...the feels!
I got quite emotional at times, which is rare nowaday.
I'm very much glad I decided to play this; it's lovable and memorable.

reviewText:
To The Moon genuinely hits a high mark; It's truly got one of the most interesting stories that I've ever sat through in video games ever.

You play as two doctors Eva and Watts who are traversing through the memories of a dying patient who's final wish is to go to the moon. I won't reveal any more to the plot because it's much better you sit through the events of the story yourself. It's tearjerking; everyone's review that says this truly means it. I didn't understand the story fully the first time mostly out of the fact that I didn't exactly understand the side-effects of some medical conditions mentioned throughout the game, Google anything you're unfamiliar with; it'll help you out, but after the 2nd time it finally made sense, and when you DO understand every piece of the story, it just hurts in a satisfying, remorseful way. There's no easy way to put it; if you don't feel ANYTHING at the end of the gorgeous ride the game takes you through, you're unbelievably heartless.

If stories that certainly make you appreciate life and not take it for granted, and a hint of science fiction is your cup of tea, To The Moon does anything but disappoint. The piano-arranged soundtrack is stunning; I still find myself humming the themes 3-years later, the 16-bit graphics are nice, and the mini-puzzles inbetween are a lovely touch to keep you going. I'm super excited for Kan Gao's next installment to the series 'Finding Paradise' later this year, but for now I will continue to love this game to no end.

Thanks, Kan.

reviewText: To The Moon is a game about 2 scientists/doctors who help grant the wishes of people on their deathbeds by altering their memories. They respond to a call from the caretaker of a man that wants to go to the moon, and so the scientists travel through his memories in order to alter them. reviewText:
I purchased To the Moon on a whim because it had strong reviews and was on sale. Plus, the game description intrigued me, and I thought if nothing else, it might be a decent way to spend the evening.

Four hours later, and I am crying harder than I have in months.

I honestly don't know how to describe this game without spoiling the magic of it. This is one of the titles I will point to when people contend that video games cannot be art. They absolutely can be, and this indie might well be considered a masterpiece. The story of To the Moon is tragic, beautiful, and sad. It is often funny and sometimes hilarious. It is the first video game that ever stirred my emotions to the point of tears. And it gave me a newfound appreciation for life. Seriously.

Some details would probably be helpful. You play as Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts, two specialists who are hired to modify clients' memories so that the last thing they remember on their deathbeds is the fulfillment of a grand and final wish. This is achieved by working backwards through the patient's remembered life, planting the seed of an idea in their early childhood so that their new, artificial life will play out the way it needs to in order for the wish to take hold. Their latest job is an old man named Johnny, a widower who wants to go to the moon. Only thing is, he doesn't remember why he wants to go, only that he must. So our heroes set up their equipment, enter his most recent memory, and start seeing the man's life in reverse.

What begins as a standard point-and-click title quickly weaves into a heartbreaking and simultaneously joyous exploration of life, death, love and its flaws, dreams and the crushing feeling of losing them, promises kept and broken, the future, the past, and the importance of making the present count. It portrayed the shattering realities of illness, financial woes, selfishness, and failure. It captured the grief of not understanding someone you love and the tragedies that befall all of us. It illustrates how love is powerful but also incredibly painful and complex. It makes you think about how each one of us is the hero of our own story, and how much it hurts when we don't live up to the title. It makes you think about how we take so many things and people for granted, and the peculiarities of what does and doesn't stick in our memory. It shows us the importance and the absurdity of chasing after nostalgia, of knowing that something in your possession matters but not remembering why. It shows how easy it is to see other people's mistakes in life while ignoring our own. It pointed out how we would rather act than listen. To the Moon made me think about my own real-life relationships and how I could (should) put more effort into them. It made me think about dozens of chance encounters I've had, the dreaded What if?" It made me smile with its true-to-life depictions of talking to girls

reviewText:
A few things before the review...

I have said many times to many of my friends, that sidescrollers are just some of the most dependable games there are in the history of games.
Whether it be Super Castlevania IV, Ghosts & Goblins, Legend of Zelda, or even Gauntlet, a sidescrolling game has qualities that almost no modern game can match. Now, that aside, the To The Moon game, in itself, brought expectations for this genre, to a whole new level for me.
I would have never expected such an amazing story to be withheld inside of such a pixelated environment. I did cry quite a bit while playing this game just because I get so attached to certain things that other people may find silly.
When playing To The Moon, you have to get lost within the game itself, and forget it is a game. You have to think of it like life itself, or as a book that you are reading to see the ending. To The Moon brought what it meant to be a sidescroller, to a different playing field.

Gameplay!

Of course gameplay from a sidescroller is restricted by the dimensions in which the game is formatted on. But do not let this fool you. To The Moon has a quality while you play it that makes you forget you are even playing a sidescroller, but as if you are watching a movie. WASD are of course very prevalent in this game, and using a mouse and or trackpad to click and interact with things are also a major factor. In the inchoate stages of the game, you will find that it brings you through the gist of how things are done.
It is not hard to catch hold of how the game is played, for there are only a few controls used within the game itself.

Story

I do not want to spoil the story within a review, but I will say that the story is the most monolithic part of the game itself. If it weren't for this, nobody would have wanted to play this game.
However, within this review, I will tell you a bit about the main characters that you would be playing!
Eva and Neil are the two scientists that you will be playing as throughout the entirety of the game. They crack jokes at each other back and forth using anything from puns, to movie and game jokes. They even go as far as to use memes within the game itself. This just provides the much loved comic relief that makes the game so much more enjoyable than it would be without it.
Of course the main characters do have serious points in the story, mostly when a major event is taking place, or when the change in mood occurs.

Artwork and Music

Like I have said many times before, music will make a game very memorable.
Whether it be the nostalgic tune of Castlevania's Bloody Tears
date:
or the ever so standoutish songs from the modern Final Fantasy series.
Within To The Moon, lies some of the most beautiful piano work that could be put into a game. It is simplistic, but it is also some of the most fitting music that could go with the scenes of the game.

The artwork, of course, is pixelated. There is no big surprise there, but there is much skill within a pixelated game. There can be some of the most amazing art in pixel format, that nobody would ever see just because the game is pixelated.
Some of the more recommendable sidescrollers with similar art would be the Gundemonium series, or the Super Nintendo's memorable, Super Mario World."

All in all
recommended: this game is a 9.5 out of 10 that I would play again and again if given the time :3"

reviewText:
Recently, I just finished playing To the Moon along with the two minisodes that come after it and I have to say that this game deserves all the positive praise that it has received.  Without becoming too verbose, this game has one of the best written storylines that I've read in a while and it's one of the very few games in which I've ever cried.  I cried in two places near the end because it was just so emotional that it was difficult to keep my feelings in check.  It was well thought out and it had the perfect timing when the dialogue needed to be there versus when it was more appropriate just to see the events happen.  I would reveal what the story is about but that would be a major spoiler and besides, it would be much better to buy this game and play it for yourself.  ;D  If you're looking more for a traditional RPG, this game isn't it but if you're looking for a great storyline, then it's right up your alley.

After playing this game, then play the two minisodes in order.  They reveal fun extras as to what happens after To the Moon.  The second minisode is especially worth it, once you see what happens towards the very end.  It will leave you guessing as to what's really going on.

I can't say much more than that.  The soundtrack was beautiful as well and very pleasing to listen to.  I'm planning on replaying the game when I have the time, as it was very enjoyable and I feel that a second playthough would help me to better understand the story more (although I did get it mostly on my first playthrough).

What was really nice was seeing the new locations and scenarios.\n\n9/10

reviewText: This is NOT a game. It is a story that is played through, without much action by the player. Think of it as more of a slide show on steroids where you get to click the conversation along. Very good storyline, I will rate the story a 10/10, which speaks alot. On the other hand, as it is like a movie, the actual playtime is averaged at 1 hour per playthrough and since it is story based, there is no replayability. My take? Get this if you are buying it on discount, but I definitely wouldn't pay a full 10 bucks for a 1 hour game with no replayability. Very interesting note - This game was made using the RPGMaker engine which can be bought as a separate program for people to make their own games.

reviewText: This is one of the few Indie games I've played that really got me hooked. You don't play it for the functionality...you play it for the story. It was really unlike anything I had played before, and giving any details to the story would ruin the fun. Just buy this game when it's on sale, and it's quite a nice experience. If you don't like investing in short games, however; don't get it. I beat it in about 4 hours.

reviewText: To the Moon will be a memorable game for me. I was brought to it by the soundtrack and recommendations of people that enjoyed it as well. First of all, it's a point and click game, which can make it a little boring at times, and the controls and resolution options can be a little wonky. The small amount of puzzles were quite simple. The whole game is easy, but i really don't think the difficulty is the point of this game; rather, its strength lies in its story and character. The story kept me going even when i got bored of it, and there is just the right amount of suspense and curiousity in it. Perfect amount of suspense, because in the end it all fit perfectly. I got rather attached to the characters and setting. I finished this game in about 5 hours, so i will tell you this game is definitely worth your time, short playthrough as it is. This game is worth the odds. :)
